            <div class="pdf-viewer-page">
                                    <div id="pf1" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="1"><div class="pc pc1 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x0 y0 w1 h1" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/1.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">  <span class="ff2"> </span> <span class="ff3"> </span> <span class="ff3"> <span class="ff2"> </span></span>    </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h5 y4 ff5 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1">Annu. Rev. Mater<span class="_ _2"></span>. Sci.<span class="_ _3"> </span>1998.<span class="_ _3"> </span>28:271–98</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h6 y5 ff5 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2">Copyright <span class="ff4 fs1 v0">c</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x4 h7 y6 ff6 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls0">°<span class="ff5 fs3 ls2 ws0 v0">1998 by Annual Reviews. All rights reserved</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h8 y7 ff4 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL BONE:</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h8 y8 ff4 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Structure-Mechanical Function</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h8 y9 ff4 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls2">Relations</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 ya ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">S. W<span class="_ _2"></span>einer and H. D. W<span class="_ _2"></span>agner<span class="_ _3"></span><span class="ff6 fs1 v1">∗</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 ha yb ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Departments of Structural Biology and Materials and Interfaces, <span class="ff6 fs3 ls1 v2">∗</span>W<span class="_ _2"></span>eizmann Institute</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 ha yc ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">of Science, 76100 Rehovot, Israel; e-mail: ciweiner@weizmann.weizmann.ac.il;</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 ha yd ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3">cpwagner@wis.weizmann.ac.il</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 ye ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">KEY WORDS:<span class="_ _4"> </span>biomineralization, biomechanics, lamellar bone, mineralized collagen, bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x5 h3 yf ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2">mineral</div>
<div class="t m0 x6 h4 y10 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">A<span class="fs1">BSTRACT</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y11 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5">The term bone refers to a family of materials, all of which are built up of miner-</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y12 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6">alized collagen fibrils.<span class="_ _5"> </span>They have highly complex structures, described in terms</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y13 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7">of up to 7 hierarchical levels of organization. These materials have e<span class="_ _2"></span>volved to</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y14 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8">fulfill a variety of mechanical functions, for which the structures are presumably</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y15 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9">fine-tuned. Matching structure to function is a challenge. Here we review the</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y16 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa">structure-mechanical relations at each of the hierarchical levels of organization,</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y17 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb">highlighting wherever possible both underlying strategies and gaps in our knowl-</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y18 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc">edge.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The insights gained from the study of these fascinating materials are not</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y19 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd">only important biologically, but may well pro<span class="_ _2"></span>vide novel ideas that can be applied</div>
<div class="t m0 x7 ha y1a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">to the design of synthetic materials.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y1b ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse">INTRODUCTION</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">Bone refers to a family of materials each with a somewhat different structural</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10">motif, but all having in common the basic building block, the mineralized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11">collagen fibril.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This family of materials also contains other members, which</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12">for historical reasons, have different names.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The better known examples are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y20 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13">dentin, the material that constitutes the inner layers of teeth; cementum,<span class="_ _5"> </span>the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y21 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14">thin layer that binds the roots of teeth to the jaw; and mineralized tendons.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y22 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15">Here we review the structure-mechanical function relations of these materials,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y23 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16">highlighting wherever possible the basic underlying themes.<span class="_ _8"> </span>W<span class="_ _2"></span>e emphasize</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y24 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">the mechanical functions, although some of these materials also fulfill other</div>
<div class="t m0 x8 h4 y25 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">271</div>
<div class="t m0 x9 h4 y26 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">0084-6600/98/0801-0271$08.00</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

                            </div>

                                                <div class="rg-wayPoint" data-track-url="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/track/consume-asset?pid=234151607&lid=53f0439e0cf26b9b7dcdf6fa&fp=9cb343876f5cdda96e38041808236efed0dff906&init=1"></div>

                        <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="1">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf2" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="2"><div class="pc pc2 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">    </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">272 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">functions.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Many bones, for example, are also the major reservoirs of calcium</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">and phosphate necessary for a wide variety of metabolic functions.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1a">The diversity of structures within this family reflects the fine-tuning or adap-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">tation of the structure to its function.<span class="_ _6"> </span>This diversity thus provides us with an</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1c">invaluable research handle that when used in a comparati<span class="_ _2"></span>ve way can provide</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">key insights into the relations between structure and function.<span class="_ _5"> </span>This approach,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1e">powerful as it may be, needs to be used with caution.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Biological structures are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">not necessarily perfectly adapted to function, although the millions of years de-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">voted<span class="_ _3"></span>to<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>fine-tuning<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>this<span class="_ _3"> </span>relation<span class="_ _3"> </span>has<span class="_ _3"> </span>produced<span class="_ _3"> </span>some<span class="_ _3"> </span>remarkable<span class="_ _3"> </span>solutions</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12">to tough structural-mechanical problems.<span class="_ _7"> </span>An exciting prospect for the study</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws20">of such biological materials is to identify these “novel” solutions and possibly</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws21">apply some to solve problems in synthetic materials.<span class="_ _5"> </span>It is also important not to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws22">assume that each member of the family fulfills one or only several functions.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws23">This may well be the case, but the contrary may also occur—the overall design</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws24">strategy is to achieve an all-purpose material (the concretes of the biological</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws25">world) that will function adequately, if not optimally<span class="_ _2"></span>, under many conditions.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">Finally, these biological materials are no dif<span class="_ _2"></span>ferent from many synthetic mate-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">rials that are required, for example, to function well under compression, but</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">also on occasion need to withstand serious challenges from impacting and/or</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">bending stresses.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Thus the term function in our title is fraught with difficulty;</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">unfortunately, so is the term structure.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y3f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">The basic building block of the bone family of materials is the mineralized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y40 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">collagen<span class="_ _3"></span>fibril. It<span class="_ _3"></span>is<span class="_ _3"></span>composed<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>fibrous<span class="_ _9"></span>protein<span class="_ _9"></span>collagen<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>structural<span class="_ _3"> </span>form</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y41 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws29">that is also present in skin, tendon, and a variety of other soft tissues.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The colla-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y42 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">gen constitutes the main component of a three-dimensional matrix into which,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y43 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">and in some cases onto which, the mineral forms.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The mineral in this family</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 hc y44 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2c">of materials is dahllite, also known as carbonated apatite (Ca<span class="fs3 ls3 v3">5</span><span class="ws4 v0">(PO<span class="fs3 ws2d v3">4</span><span class="ls4 ws2e">,C<span class="_ _a"></span>O</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 xd h5 y45 ff4 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls5">3</div>
<div class="t m0 xe h4 y46 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls4">)</div>
<div class="t m0 xf h5 y45 ff4 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls5">3</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y47 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">(OH)) (1).<span class="_ _7"> </span>The third major component is water.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The major components are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y48 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">intimately associated into an ordered structure, the mineralized collagen fibril.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y49 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws30">Their proportions, however<span class="_ _2"></span>, can vary considerably between family members.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">The manner in which the building blocks are organized into higher order struc-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws32">tures can also vary<span class="_ _2"></span>,<span class="_ _6"> </span>and in fact, this is the basis for differentiating between</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">the members of the bone family of biological materials.<span class="_ _5"> </span>T<span class="_ _2"></span>o further complicate</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">matters, some of these materials are composed of two different organizational</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">motifs that are juxtaposed, and in turn the whole structure may be folded into</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws20">even larger suprastructures (re<span class="_ _2"></span>viewed in 2, 3). Thus there is no meaning to the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y50 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws35">term the structure of bone, but rather the structures of these materials have to be</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y51 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws36">understood both in terms of the differences between family members, and most</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y52 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">importantly<span class="_ _3"></span>according<span class="_ _3"></span>to<span class="_ _3"></span>hierarchical<span class="_ _3"></span>levels<span class="_ _9"></span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>organization. Figure<span class="_ _3"> </span>1<span class="_ _3"> </span>illustrates</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y53 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">the 7 levels of hierarchical organization of the family of mineralized collagen</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y54 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">based materials as we envisage it.</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="1">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf3" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="3"><div class="pc pc3 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x10 y55 w2 hd lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/3.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">  <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y56 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws39">Figure 1<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">The 7 hierarchical lev<span class="_ _2"></span>els of organization of the bone family of materials.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Level 1:</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y57 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3a">Isolated crystals from human bone (<span class="ff5">left side</span>) and part of an unmineralized and unstained collagen</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y58 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3b">fibril<span class="_ _9"></span>from<span class="_ _9"> </span>turkey<span class="_ _3"> </span>tendon<span class="_ _9"></span>observed<span class="_ _9"></span>in<span class="_ _9"> </span>vitreous<span class="_ _3"> </span>ice<span class="_ _9"></span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>TEM<span class="_ _9"> </span>(<span class="ff5">right<span class="_ _3"> </span>side</span><span class="ws3c">). Level<span class="_ _9"></span>2: TEM<span class="_ _9"></span>micrograph</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y59 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3d">of a mineralized collagen fibril from turkey tendon.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Level 3:<span class="_ _5"> </span>TEM micrograph of a thin section</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y5a ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3e">of mineralized turkey tendon.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Level 4: Four fibril array patterns of organization found in the bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y5b ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3f">family of materials.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Level 5:<span class="_ _3"> </span>SEM micrograph of a single osteon from human bone.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Level 6:<span class="_ _b"> </span>Light</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y5c ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws40">micrograph of a fractured section through a fossilized (about 5500 years old) human femur. Level</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y5d ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">7:<span class="_ _b"> </span>Whole bovine bone (scale:<span class="_ _b"> </span>10 cm).</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="2">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf4" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="4"><div class="pc pc4 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">    </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">274 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">Many measurements of the bulk elastic, plastic, and ultimate properties of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">certain members of the bone family of materials have been made.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Figure 2 is</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">a plot of the moduli and strengths of several bone types measured parallel and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">perpendicular to the bone long axes.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The range of these values reflects many</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">different variables:<span class="_ _b"> </span>the diversity in structures, the orientation of the specimens,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">the variations in mineralization extent and porosity<span class="_ _2"></span>, the precise locations of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws45">the specimens, and not insignificantly, the variations in the procedures used for</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">making<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>measurements. It<span class="_ _3"></span>is<span class="_ _3"></span>clearly<span class="_ _3"></span>important<span class="_ _3"></span>to<span class="_ _3"></span>sort<span class="_ _3"></span>out<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>contributions<span class="_ _3"> </span>of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15">all these variables to the bulk mechanical properties—the focus of this revie<span class="_ _2"></span>w.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">Understanding structure-function relations in these materials is therefore a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">challenge.<span class="_ _6"> </span>W<span class="_ _2"></span>e are easily able to measure bulk mechanical properties of some</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">family members and in some special cases obtain information on certain of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws25">the intermediate hierarchical levels, but how can these be related to the struc-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws47">tures themselves?<span class="_ _7"> </span>An in-depth understanding of this subject ideally requires</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">sorting out the bulk mechanical behavior in terms of the contributions of the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">sub-structures at each hierarchical level.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Unfortunately, even if we were able to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">comprehensively describe these materials in this way<span class="_ _2"></span>, this still would not con-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1c">stitute an adequate analysis, as many of these materials actually change with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4a">time.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This in turn affects the mechanical properties.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Some of these changes</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">are in part thermodynamically driven, such as the increase in the sizes of the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">crystals, and some are also biologically mediated, such as the determination</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">of the average proportions of collagen, mineral, and water in a giv<span class="_ _2"></span>en material.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y40 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">Furthermore, specialized bone cells actively remove older bone and replace it</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y41 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">with younger bone, which may even have a slightly dif<span class="_ _2"></span>ferent structure such that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y42 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4f">it is presumably optimized to function in the prevailing stress field at the time</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y43 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">of its formation (4).<span class="_ _5"> </span>In this sense, these materials are really “smart.”</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y44 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">The investigations to date of the structure-function relations of the bone fam-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">ily<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>materials<span class="_ _3"> </span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>for<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>most<span class="_ _3"> </span>part<span class="_ _3"> </span>unable<span class="_ _3"> </span>to<span class="_ _3"> </span>provide<span class="_ _3"></span>anywhere<span class="_ _9"></span>near<span class="_ _3"> </span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>complete</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws51">picture of this subject.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Despite this inadequacy, we have chosen to organize</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y60 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws35">this review according to the hierarchical lev<span class="_ _2"></span>els of organization.<span class="_ _5"> </span>We discuss 5 of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y61 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1e">the 7 hierarchical levels, which range in scale from nanometers to millimeters,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y62 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">in terms of their structures and mechanical properties.<span class="_ _6"> </span>These relations in the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y63 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">more macroscopic structures have been revie<span class="_ _2"></span>wed extensively elsewhere (2,<span class="_ _9"></span>5).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y64 ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 1:<span class="_ _5"> </span>THE MAJOR COMPONENTS</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y65 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws53">Dahllite (carbonated apatite) crystals, type I collagen fibrils, and water are the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y66 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">major components of the bone family of materials.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Whereas dahllite is the only</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y67 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws22">mineral type in mature bone, type I collagen is by no means the only protein</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y68 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">present.<span class="_ _8"> </span>There are two hundred or more so-called non-collagenous proteins</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y69 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws55">(NCPs) (6), but together they generally comprise less than 10% of the total</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

                                    </div>

                            </div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="2">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf5" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="5"><div class="pc pc5 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x3 y6a w3 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/5.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">275</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y6b ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws56">Figure 2<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Strength versus modulus of v<span class="_ _2"></span>arious bone types under different loading modes, in direc-</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y6c ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws57">tions parallel and perpendicular to the bone long axes.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The <span class="ff5 ws58">circles </span>and <span class="ff5 ws58">inverted triangles </span>are for</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y6d ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws58">baboon tibia planar (circumferential) lamellar bone and osteonal bone, respectively, measured in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y6e ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws59">bending (data from 72); the <span class="ff5">squares, diamonds, </span>and <span class="ff5">triangles </span>are for human femur osteonal bone,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y6f ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5a">bovine femur fibrolamellar bone, and bovine femur parallel-fibered bone, respectively<span class="_ _2"></span>, measured</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y70 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5b">in tension (data from 49); <span class="ff5 ws5c">hexagons </span>are for mineralized turkey tendon (gastrocnemius) measured in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y71 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5d">tension (data from 47).<span class="_ _b"> </span>The insert shows the same values but has an expanded scale.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Note that in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y72 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5e">the latter, proportionality between strength and modulus arises from a progressive change in ash</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y73 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">weight (mineral content), rather than an increase in structural isotropy.</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="3">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf6" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="6"><div class="pc pc6 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff3"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">276 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5f">protein content.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Although some of these proteins may contribute to the mecha-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">nical functions, we have no direct evidence for this. Nor do we kno<span class="_ _2"></span>w whether</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12">lipids, which may also be present in fairly large amounts in some bones (7),</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">have any mechanical function.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y74 ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Dahllite Crystals</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y75 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">The crystals of bone are plate-shaped, with average lengths and widths of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y76 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">50 <span class="ff6 ls6">×</span><span class="ws0">25 nm (Figure 1; Level 1) (8–10). The crystals are very thin, with thick-</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y77 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws62">nesses appearing (in transmission electron microscopy; TEM) to be remark-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y78 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws63">ably uniform.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) is a more reliable means</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y79 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">of measuring their smallest dimensions, and the results vary from just 1.5 nm</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">for mineralized tendon up to about 4.0 nm for some mature bone types (11, 12).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws64">These crystals are therefore extremely small—in fact they are probably the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">smallest biologically formed crystals known (10).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Unfortunately, we still know</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">very little about their surface atomic structures.<span class="_ _6"> </span>An atomic force microscopy</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">(AFM) study of synthetic apatite shows that the surface is highly ordered and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y7f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">matches the bulk structure (13). Nor do we know for sure why these crys-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y80 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws68">tals are plate-shaped, even though dahllite has hexagonal crystal symmetry<span class="_ _2"></span>.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y81 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws69">One proposed explanation is that they grow via an octacalcium phosphate</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y82 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6a">transition phase (14). Octacalcium phosphate crystals are plate-shaped and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y83 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">have a structure very similar to apatite, except for the presence of a hydrated</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y84 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">layer.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y85 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Reliable<span class="_ _9"></span>measurements<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>mechanical<span class="_ _3"> </span>properties<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>biological<span class="_ _3"></span>dahllite<span class="_ _3"></span>are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y86 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">important for understanding bone properties.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Measurements on single crystals</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y87 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6c">have not been made to date, presumably because of their small size.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Powders</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y88 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">under pressure or compact polycrystalline materials have been measured usu-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y89 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">ally by sonic velocity<span class="_ _2"></span>, and the results are compared with measurements<span class="_ _9"></span>made on</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">large geological single crystals (15).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Young’<span class="_ _2"></span>s modulus of synthetic powdered</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">carbonated apatite is 109 GPa, whereas it is 114 GPa for a large single crystal of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">hydroxyapatite.<span class="_ _5"> </span>We are not aware of a similar measurement made on crystals</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">extracted from bone.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y8e ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">The T<span class="_ _2"></span>ype I Collagen Fibril</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6f">T<span class="_ _2"></span>ype I collagen is characterized by its fibrous nature, with the fibrils in bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y90 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">generally about 80–100 nm in diameter, when measured in the TEM (Figure 1;</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y91 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">Level 1).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Their lengths are in effect unknown, because they tend to merge with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y92 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">neighboring fibrils (16,<span class="_ _3"></span>17).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Each fibril is made up of three polypeptide chains</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y93 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">about 1000 amino acids long.<span class="_ _7"> </span>These are wound together in a triple helix.<span class="_ _6"> </span>A</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y94 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">triple-helical molecule is thus cylindrically shaped, with an average diameter</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y95 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">of about 1.5 nm, and lengths of 300 nm (reviewed in 10,<span class="_ _9"></span>18, 19).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The manner</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y96 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">in which they pack to form a fibril is most unusual (19).<span class="_ _5"> </span>In an imaginary slice</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="3">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf7" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="7"><div class="pc pc7 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x12 y97 w4 hf lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/7.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2">  </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">277</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y98 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws72">Figure 3<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Schematic illustrations (not drawn to scale) of the structure of collagen in terms of</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y99 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws73">the organization of the triple-helical molecules.<span class="_ _5"> </span>(<span class="ff5">a, left side</span>) Slice about 1.5 nm thick through a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y9a ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws74">fibril, showing the staggered array pattern first proposed by Hodge & Petruska (20); (<span class="ff5">a, right side</span>)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y9b ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws75">three-dimensional model showing the alignment of the holes to form a channel (21).<span class="_ _5"> </span>(<span class="ff5 ws3b">b</span>) Model</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y9c ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws40">showing the proposed location of the platy crystals in the channels (3). The arrows show the three</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y9d ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">principal symmetry directions.<span class="_ _6"> </span>In parallel-fibered bone, T is in the plane transverse to the bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y9e ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">long axis and P is in the plane parallel to the natural outer surface of the bone (48).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y9f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">through a fibril, 1.5 nm thick (i.e.<span class="_ _5"> </span>the thickness of one triple-helical molecule),</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws77">the triple-helical molecules are all parallel, but their ends are separated by</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4f">holes of about 35 nm (Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">a</span>).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Furthermore, the neighboring triple-helical</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">molecules are offset or staggered by 68 nm (20).<span class="_ _5"> </span>In a second imaginary slice</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">orthogonal to the first, no offset is present and the triple-helical molecules, as</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">well as the holes, are aligned (Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">a</span>) (21).<span class="_ _5"> </span>One key point is that the internal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1e">structure of the fibril does not have radial symmetry but is dif<span class="_ _2"></span>ferent in all three</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">orthogonal directions.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 ya7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">Fibrils almost never exist alone in biological tissues, including the members</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">of the bone family.<span class="_ _6"> </span>They associate with each other to form arrays of aligned</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ya9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">fibrils that make up a larger structure called the fiber<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _7"> </span>It is thus very difficult</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yaa ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7b">to measure the mechanical properties of an individual fibril.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Furthermore, the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yab ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">packing of fibrils in a fiber may vary from one tissue to another and influence</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yac ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">the mechanical properties.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 yad ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse">W<span class="_ _2"></span>ater</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y65 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">W<span class="_ _2"></span>ater is the third major component of the bone family of materials.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The impor-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y66 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">tance<span class="_ _9"></span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>water<span class="_ _3"> </span>for<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>mechanical<span class="_ _9"></span>functioning<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"> </span>cannot<span class="_ _3"></span>be<span class="_ _9"></span>underestimated.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y67 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Mechanical<span class="_ _9"></span>measurements<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>dry<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _9"></span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>different<span class="_ _3"> </span>from<span class="_ _3"></span>those<span class="_ _9"></span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>wet<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"></span>(22).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y68 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7e">The water is located within the fibril, in the gaps, and between triple-helical</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y69 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">molecules.<span class="_ _5"> </span>It is also present between fibrils and between fibers (23).</div>

                                    <div id="pf8" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="8"><div class="pc pc8 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x10 yae w2 h10 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/8.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">278 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 yaf ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">The Relative Proportions of the Thr<span class="_ _2"></span>ee Major Components</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7f">The relative proportions of mineral, collagen, and water vary in a systematic</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">manner between bone types (24).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The volume relationships in particular show</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">that the collagen content remains basically the same, whereas the increase in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">mineral content occurs at the expense of the water content.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The average propor-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">tions are fixed for any given bone by a comple<span class="_ _2"></span>x and only partially understood</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">biological process.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The mineral component, in addition, increases with increas-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">ing time, as the crystals continue to grow<span class="_ _2"></span>.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yb7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">Currey (22, 25) has performed a series of studies of the relationships between</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">mineral<span class="_ _9"></span>content<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>mechanical<span class="_ _3"> </span>properties. The<span class="_ _3"> </span>approach<span class="_ _3"> </span>has<span class="_ _3"></span>been<span class="_ _3"></span>to<span class="_ _9"></span>test<span class="_ _3"> </span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>very</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yb9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">large sample of bones, e<span class="_ _2"></span>ven though they have<span class="_ _9"></span>different porosities and structures.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yba ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws84">The results still clearly indicate that the Y<span class="_ _2"></span>oung’s modulus of compact bone in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ybb ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws85">tension shows a strong positive relationship with mineral content (Figure 4)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ybc ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws86">(25).<span class="_ _7"> </span>The ultimate strain and the work under the stress-strain curve decrease</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 ybd ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws87">Figure 4<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Plot of the calcium content versus Y<span class="_ _2"></span>oung’s modulus for a lar<span class="_ _2"></span>ge variey of bones (data</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 ybe ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">from 25).</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="4">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf9" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="9"><div class="pc pc9 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x13 ybf w5 h11 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/9.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">279</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">with increasing mineral content (22).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Interestingly, some of the most unusual</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">bones at both ends of the mineral content spectrum have somewhat anomalous</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">mechanical properties.<span class="_ _4"> </span>A fascinating example is the rostrum of the whale,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Mesoplodon,<span class="_ _3"></span>which<span class="_ _9"></span>has<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>highest<span class="_ _9"></span>mineral<span class="_ _3"> </span>content<span class="_ _3"> </span>(87<span class="_ _3"></span>wt%)<span class="_ _9"></span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>all<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>members</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws89">of the bone family (26).<span class="_ _8"> </span>The organization of the crystals is similar to other</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8a">bones, yet the collagen content and characteristics are quite different (27).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8b">Mechanical tests show that it is the stiffest (Y<span class="_ _2"></span>oung’<span class="_ _2"></span>s modulus 49.6 GPa) and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws62">hardest<span class="_ _3"></span>bone<span class="_ _9"></span>tested<span class="_ _3"> </span>(28). This<span class="_ _3"> </span>raises<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>interesting<span class="_ _3"> </span>possibility<span class="_ _3"> </span>that<span class="_ _3"> </span>collagen<span class="_ _3"> </span>was</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">present<span class="_ _9"></span>during<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>early<span class="_ _9"></span>stages<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>formation<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>rostrum,<span class="_ _3"> </span>but<span class="_ _9"></span>was<span class="_ _3"> </span>subsequently</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8c">removed, allowing crystals to continue to grow<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Do similar processes, albeit</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">not so severe, occur during the normal ongoing mineralization process?</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 ycb ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Mechanical Implications</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ycc ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">The three major components of bone have completely different properties.<span class="_ _5"> </span>In</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ycd ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8d">this sense the material is clearly a composite.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The host organic framework has</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yce ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8e">a fibrous structure at the level of individual triple-helical molecules, at the le<span class="_ _2"></span>vel</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ycf ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">of fibrils (Level 2), and at the level of assemblages of fibrils (Le<span class="_ _2"></span>vel 3) that form</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">fibers.<span class="_ _6"> </span>In contrast, within a fibril,<span class="_ _5"> </span>the structure is crystalline with orthotropic</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">symmetry (Figure 3).<span class="_ _6"> </span>This implies the presence of three planes of symmetry</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">orthogonal to each other (Figure 5).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The guests in this composite are the plate-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws90">shaped crystals.<span class="_ _5"> </span>In this respect, bone should be viewed as a platelet-reinforced</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">composite (29).<span class="_ _5"> </span>To complicate matters further<span class="_ _2"></span>, the atomic lattice symmetry of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">the crystals is hexagonal, despite their platy shape.<span class="_ _6"> </span>It would be of interest to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws91">know if the mechanical properties of individual crystals are really similar to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">those measured from compressed powders.<span class="_ _6"> </span>With the advent of new stiff tips</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yd8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">for AFM, measurements of this type may be possible.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 yd9 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws92">Figure 5<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Schematic illustration (not drawn to scale) sho<span class="_ _2"></span>wing (<span class="ff5 ws3b">a</span>) an arrangement of mineral-</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 yda ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">ized collagen fibrils aligned both with respect to crystal layers and fibril axes. This structure has</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 ydb ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws94">orthotropic symmetry.<span class="_ _5"> </span>(<span class="ff5 ws3b">b</span>) Arrangement of mineralized collagen fibrils with only the fibril axes</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 ydc ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">aligned.<span class="_ _b"> </span>This structure has transversal isotropy.</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>

</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="5">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pfa" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="a"><div class="pc pca w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> </span> </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">280 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 ydd ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 2:<span class="_ _5"> </span>THE MINERALIZED COLLAGEN</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 yde ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">FIBRIL BUILDING BLOCK</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ydf ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Robinson<span class="_ _9"></span>&<span class="_ _3"> </span>Watson’s<span class="_ _9"></span>(30)<span class="_ _9"></span>pioneering<span class="_ _3"> </span>TEM<span class="_ _3"> </span>study<span class="_ _3"> </span>reported<span class="_ _3"> </span>that<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>68-nm<span class="_ _3"> </span>band-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">ing pattern of stained unmineralized collagen fibrils (Figure 1; Level 1) can also</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">be seen in unstained but mineralized collagen fibrils (Figure 1; Level 2).<span class="_ _5"> </span>This</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws95">implies that the stain and the mineral are at the same location within the fibril,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4f">i.e.<span class="_ _5"> </span>mainly within the gap regions.<span class="_ _6"> </span>TEM observations of unstained individual</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws96">mineralized collagen fibrils, both after freeze-drying and hydration in vitreous</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">ice (31,<span class="_ _3"></span>32), showed that the platy crystals are organized in layers that trav<span class="_ _2"></span>erse</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">across the fibril (Figure 1; Level 2).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Furthermore, electron diffraction patterns</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">show that the crystallographic <span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>-axes are well aligned with the fibril long axis;</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws77">a relation first observed by Schmidt (33) using polarized light microscopy<span class="_ _2"></span>.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 ye9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">This layered organizational motif has been confirmed using three-dimensional</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yea ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws25">electron tomography (34), as well as by AFM (35).<span class="_ _6"> </span>The layered arrangement</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yeb ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">of crystals can be easily accommodated inside the collagen fibril (Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yec ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">Examinations of individual mineralized fibrils from turkey tendon at different</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yed ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">tilt angles, show that they are ellipsoid in cross-section, with the crystal layers</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yee ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">aligned with the longer axis of the ellipse (31).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yef ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws99">As always in the field of bone structure, the static model is an oversimplifi-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">cation.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Studies of crystal growth in collagen fibrils show that the first-formed</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">crystals<span class="_ _9"></span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>indeed<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>hole<span class="_ _3"> </span>zone<span class="_ _3"></span>(channels)<span class="_ _9"></span>(36,<span class="_ _3"> </span>37)<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>during<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>first<span class="_ _3"></span>stages</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9a">are confined to this zone (32). However<span class="_ _2"></span>, they continue to grow and penetrate</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9b">into the overlap zone (Figure 3) (38).<span class="_ _7"> </span>In so doing, they must push aside the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9c">triple-helical<span class="_ _9"></span>molecules. Measurements<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>average<span class="_ _3"> </span>distances<span class="_ _9"></span>between<span class="_ _3"> </span>triple-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">helical molecules in fibers with mineral and those without show a decrease in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">distance from about 1.5 to 1.1 nm (39,<span class="_ _3"></span>40).<span class="_ _5"> </span>In addition to direct compression,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7b">more space may also be created by partial or (as noted for the whale rostrum)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yf8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">almost complete removal of the collagen.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yf9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">A<span class="_ _9"></span>key<span class="_ _3"> </span>question<span class="_ _3"> </span>is<span class="_ _3"></span>whether<span class="_ _9"></span>an<span class="_ _3"> </span>appreciable<span class="_ _3"> </span>volume<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>crystals<span class="_ _3"> </span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>present<span class="_ _3"> </span>outside</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yfa ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9d">the fibrils. Katz & Li (23) ingeniously combined structural and volumetric</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yfb ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">information<span class="_ _3"></span>to<span class="_ _3"> </span>infer<span class="_ _3"> </span>that<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"> </span>an<span class="_ _3"> </span>appreciable<span class="_ _3"> </span>amount<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _b"> </span>mineral<span class="_ _3"></span>is<span class="_ _3"></span>outside</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yfc ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">the<span class="_ _9"></span>fibrils. Loci<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>disordered<span class="_ _9"></span>crystals<span class="_ _3"> </span>have<span class="_ _9"></span>also<span class="_ _3"> </span>been<span class="_ _3"></span>observed<span class="_ _9"></span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>some<span class="_ _9"></span>members</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yfd ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">of this family (41,<span class="_ _9"></span>42).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The extent to which this occurs may vary considerably</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yfe ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">between members of the bone family and needs to be better documented.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 yff ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Mechanical Implications</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y100 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws86">The organization of the platy crystals in layers across the fibril indicates that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y101 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6c">at this level the structure is a platelet-reinforced fibril and is fully orthotropic.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y102 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9f">During the early stages of mineralization, the matrix host limits crystal growth</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y103 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">and keeps the crystals separate from each other, at least along the length of the</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="5">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pfb" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="b"><div class="pc pcb w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">    </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">281</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">fibril.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The crystals continue to grow<span class="_ _2"></span>, compressing the triple-helical molecules,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8d">and eventually join together to form extended sheets. At this stage the crystals</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws63">can be regarded as having been “straight-jacketed” by the organic frame<span class="_ _2"></span>work</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa1">(43).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Clearly the mechanical properties of the collagen fibrils change consid-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">erably under such conditions.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">An interesting point concerns the nature and role of the interface between the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">reinforcing mineral phase and its embedding protein matrix.<span class="_ _6"> </span>It is well known</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">that the interface plays a critical role in governing specific properties such as</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa2">compressive and shear<span class="_ _9"></span>behavior, fracture modes and<span class="_ _9"></span>toughness, as well as stress</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7e">transfer<span class="_ _9"></span>from<span class="_ _3"> </span>externally<span class="_ _9"></span>applied<span class="_ _3"> </span>loads<span class="_ _9"></span>to<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>reinforcement. The<span class="_ _9"></span>chemistry<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa3">interface in artificial composites may be tailored for specific functions because</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y104 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa2">in certain cases a weaker<span class="_ _9"></span>interface is desirable, whereas in other cases a<span class="_ _9"></span>stronger</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y105 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">interface is preferred.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The interface between collagen and apatite crystals is</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y106 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa4">poorly understood.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The fact that the collagen framework, directly or indirectly<span class="_ _2"></span>,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y107 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">both orients and controls crystal growth suggests that it could approximate a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y108 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">perfect or ideally strong interface.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Thus the primary design of such a composite</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y109 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">is probably oriented by nature toward a strong and stiff structure.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y10a ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 3:<span class="_ _5"> </span>FIBRIL ARRAYS</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws95">In the bone family of materials, mineralized collagen fibrils are almost always</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa5">present in bundles or arrays aligned along their lengths (44) (Figure 1; Level 3).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">These bundles are, howe<span class="_ _2"></span>ver, not discrete.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Fibers from one bundle may fuse with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">a neighboring bundle (16).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The detailed internal structural organization of the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">fibril arrays is another poorly documented aspect of these materials.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The major</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y110 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">gaps in our knowledge arise from the fact that the internal organization of each</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y111 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa8">fibril has an orthotropic structure.<span class="_ _8"> </span>Thus understanding fibril array structure,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y112 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">especially in terms of the mechanical implications, should address the question</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y113 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">of whether the neighboring fibrils are aligned in all three dimensions, i.e.<span class="_ _5"> </span>form</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y114 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8b">an extended crystalline structure or, at the other extreme, are aligned only to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y115 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">their fibril axes.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The difference between these two arrangements is important in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y116 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaa">terms of symmetry; one would be fully orthotropic and the other transversely</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y117 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">isotropic (Figure 5).<span class="_ _8"> </span>Furthermore,<span class="_ _6"> </span>how are the fibril arrays packed to form</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y118 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11">large ordered structures, and what is the extent of the order/disorder in these</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y119 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">structures?</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y11a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsac">The mineralized tendons of large birds, especially those from the easily</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">obtainable domestic turkey<span class="_ _2"></span>, have been studied in most detail at this level.<span class="_ _b"> </span>These</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsad">tendons are essentially arrays of type I collagen fibrils that reach macroscopic</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">(millimeters) dimensions.<span class="_ _5"> </span>They undergo mineralization starting from one end.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws46">A TEM study by Nylen et al (37) reported that if the appropriate specimen</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaf">preparation conditions are used, the fibrils are intimately associated and the</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="6">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pfc" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="c"><div class="pc pcc w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">    <span class="ff3">  <span class="ff2"> <span class="ff8"> </span></span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">282 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8e">banding patterns in neighboring fibrils are in register with each other (Figure 1;</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">Level<span class="_ _9"></span>3).<span class="_ _3"> </span>Thus<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>tendon<span class="_ _9"></span>fibril<span class="_ _3"> </span>array<span class="_ _3"> </span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>clearly<span class="_ _3"> </span>highly<span class="_ _3"> </span>ordered<span class="_ _3"></span>in<span class="_ _9"></span>two<span class="_ _3"> </span>dimensions</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws91">down<span class="_ _9"></span>to<span class="_ _3"> </span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>resolution<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>tens<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>nanometers. These<span class="_ _3"> </span>observations<span class="_ _9"></span>do<span class="_ _3"> </span>not,<span class="_ _3"> </span>however,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">address the question of three-dimensional order.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">Traub et al (32) used electron diffraction patterns of the crystals in sec-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">tions of turkey tendon to demonstrate that locally (over an area of 0.3 <span class="ff9 wsb1">μ</span>m)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">the crystal layers in several neighboring fibrils are aligned in all three dimen-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h12 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws96">sions.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The alignment must be good (better than<span class="_ _5"> </span><span class="ff6 wsb2">±</span><span class="ws4">15<span class="ff6 fs3 ls7 v2">◦</span></span><span class="v0">) because the diffraction</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h13 y120 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">pattern repeats itself every 30<span class="ff6 fs3 ls7 v2">◦</span><span class="v0">, as expected from the crystal symmetry<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _4"> </span>A</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y121 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb3">three-dimensional TEM tomographic study of bone from a chick tibia also</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y122 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">showed local alignment of crystal layers in adjacent fibrils (45).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Sonic velocity</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y123 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb5">measurements in three orthogonal directions of macroscopic specimens show</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y124 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb6">significant differences (46), implying that orthotropic order at the fibril level</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y125 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">may well extend to millimeter distances.<span class="_ _5"> </span>This in turn implies that the mechan-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y126 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">ical properties should also be different in all three directions.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y127 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1c">Mechanical measurements of macroscopic-sized mineralized tendons have</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y128 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">been made using sonic velocity (46) and in tension (47). The tension measure-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y129 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">ments show the expected strong dependence on mineral content. The stress-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws96">strain curves, howev<span class="_ _2"></span>er, have an S-shape, except for the most mineralized sam-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">ple, which behaves like other more mineralized members of this family<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">S-shape<span class="_ _9"></span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>attributed<span class="_ _9"></span>to<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>unfolding<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>higher<span class="_ _3"></span>order<span class="_ _9"></span>packing<span class="_ _3"></span>structure<span class="_ _9"></span>(crimps)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws21">known to be present in unmineralized collagen (19). Interestingly the presence</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb7">of more mineral appears to eliminate this structure (47). The unmineralized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y12f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb7">tendons have low a<span class="_ _2"></span>verage modulus values of 67 and 103 MPa, whereas the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y130 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">mineralized tendons have average v<span class="_ _2"></span>alues ranging from 162 to 825 MPa (Figure</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y131 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaf">2).<span class="_ _8"> </span>We caution against extrapolating these measurements to other members</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y132 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">of the bone family, as e<span class="_ _2"></span>ven the most mineralized tendon is poorly mineralized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y133 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">(less than 50 wt%) compared with most bones (46).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y134 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">Another member of the bone family of materials with a structure similar to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y135 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa5">tendon is parallel-fibered bone.<span class="_ _5"> </span>As its name implies, it is composed of arrays of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y136 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">mineralized fibrils aligned along their fiber<span class="_ _9"></span>axes, but its mineral content (around</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y137 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws30">65 wt% ) is much higher than mineralized tendon and is more representative</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y138 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">of most bone types. T<span class="_ _2"></span>o date there has been no detailed study of the three-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y139 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">dimensional structure of this bone type, although<span class="_ _9"></span>SEM observations support the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y13a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws86">notion that it too has long-range orthotropic order (48).<span class="_ _7"> </span>The hardness values</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y13b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">in three orthogonal directions are quite different (48).<span class="_ _6"> </span>In the plane parallel to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y13c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsba">the macroscopic bone outer surface (periosteum) (P in Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span><span class="wsbb">), the hardness</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h14 y13d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbc">values are 480 <span class="ff6 ls6">±</span>60 MPa<span class="fs3 ws2d v2">2</span><span class="v0">, and in the transverse (T in Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>) and radial</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h15 y101 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">planes,<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>values<span class="_ _3"></span>are<span class="_ _9"></span>705 <span class="ff6 ls6">±</span><span class="ws4c">90<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>600 <span class="ff6 ls6">±</span><span class="ws4">60<span class="_ _9"></span>MPa<span class="fs3 ws2d v2">2</span><span class="v0">,<span class="_ _3"> </span>respectively<span class="_ _9"></span>(1<span class="_ _3"> </span>kg/mm<span class="fs3 ls8 v2">2</span><span class="ff6">=</span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y13e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbd">9.81 MPa). The extent of anisotropy is probably much greater because the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y13f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">structure is not perfectly regular to micron-scale dimensions.<span class="_ _7"> </span>If these values</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
