            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="6">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pfd" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="d"><div class="pc pcd w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> </span> </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">283</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">are extrapolated down to the nanometer scale of the individual mineralized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbe">fibril (Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span><span class="wsbf">), the highest hardness values occur when the triple-helical</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc0">molecules are indented in the plane perpendicular to the fibril axis, and the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">crystals are indented edge-on.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The lowest values occur when the crystals are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">indented face-on and in the direction in which crystal layers are separated by</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc1">four layers of triple-helical molecules (P in Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>).<span class="_ _5"> </span>It is extremely difficult</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">to study this bone type using more informative mechanical tests, because it is</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">generally<span class="_ _9"></span>intimately<span class="_ _3"> </span>associated<span class="_ _9"></span>with<span class="_ _3"> </span>another<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _9"></span>type<span class="_ _3"> </span>(lamellar<span class="_ _3"></span>bone). A<span class="_ _9"></span>single</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws62">measurement<span class="_ _3"></span>(49)<span class="_ _9"></span>(Figure<span class="_ _3"> </span>2)<span class="_ _3"> </span>shows<span class="_ _3"> </span>that<span class="_ _3"> </span>this<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"></span>is<span class="_ _3"></span>highly<span class="_ _9"></span>anisotropic. Clearly,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">we need to improve our understanding of the elastic and ultimate properties of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">parallel-fibered bone, as fibril arrays form the basis of all the structural types</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y104 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">in this family.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y105 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc3">Even though the information is sparse, the mechanical implications are clear.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y106 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc4">Mineralized fibril arrays are highly anisotropic, with the highest modulus val-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y107 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7e">ues in tension and, especially, in compression in the direction parallel to the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y108 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc5">fibril long axes.<span class="_ _4"> </span>Thus the basic building module of this family of materi-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y109 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc6">als is anisotropic, both in structure and in mechanical properties.<span class="_ _8"> </span>This may</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y140 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws53">have advantages for some functions b<span class="_ _2"></span>ut has clear disadvantages for others.<span class="_ _5"> </span>At</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y141 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc7">the next level of organization, the structural div<span class="_ _2"></span>ersity might be at least par-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y142 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">tially rationalized in terms of extents of anisotropy or isotropy of the different</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y143 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">sturctures.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y144 ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 4:<span class="_ _5"> </span>DIVERSITY IN FIBRIL ARRAY</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y145 ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">ORGANIZA<span class="_ _2"></span>TIONAL P<span class="_ _2"></span>A<span class="_ _2"></span>TTERNS</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y146 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc9">At Level 4 the conspicuous div<span class="_ _2"></span>ersity in structure occurs,<span class="_ _6"> </span>with fibril arrays</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y147 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsca">organized in a variety of patterns.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Of course, this does not imply that structural</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y148 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa1">diversity does not exist in Le<span class="_ _2"></span>vels 1, 2, and 3.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The fibril array patterns of four</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y149 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws67">of the most common members of this family are shown in Figure 6. For a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y14a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscb">more comprehensive description of div<span class="_ _2"></span>ersity in fibril array organization see</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y14b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Francillon-Vieillot et al (50) and Pritchard (51).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y8e ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P<span class="_ _2"></span>attern 1:<span class="_ _6"> </span>Arrays of P<span class="_ _2"></span>arallel Fibrils</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y8f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">This pattern is essentially the extension of the Level 3 structure into the micron</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y90 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">and even millimeter scale size range.<span class="_ _b"> </span>We mentioned above two occurrences of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y91 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscc">this structural pattern, namely mineralized tendons and parallel-fibered bone.<span class="_ _5"> </span>It</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y92 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscd">is also found in some fish scales and in the skeletons of fish and amphibia (51).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y93 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws23">The presence of mineralized tendons in the legs of large land-bound birds such</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y94 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7f">as turkeys is somewhat unusual but con<span class="_ _2"></span>venient for study.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Far more common</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y95 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">is the phenomenon of tendons (called Sharpey’s fibers) that are mineralized in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y96 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">the zone of attachment to the bone or tooth surface (16,<span class="_ _9"></span>50).</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="7">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pfe" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="e"><div class="pc pce w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x14 y14c w6 h16 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/14.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">284 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">Parallel-fibered bone is characteristically found in the bovid family .<span class="_ _b"> </span>During</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">early development, bone of this type is formed very rapidly<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Parallel-fibered</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">bone is first laid down with the fibrils more or less parallel to the bone long axis.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws21">Fairly large sausage-shaped spaces are left between successive layers of ne<span class="_ _2"></span>wly</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbf">forming bone. These spaces are subsequently filled with another bone type</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">(lamellar bone) (2).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The combination of the two is referred to as fibrolamellar</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">bone<span class="_ _9"></span>(also<span class="_ _3"> </span>known<span class="_ _3"> </span>as<span class="_ _3"> </span>plexiform<span class="_ _9"></span>bone). As<span class="_ _3"> </span>was<span class="_ _3"> </span>noted<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>discussion<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>Level<span class="_ _3"> </span>3,</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="7">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pff" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="f"><div class="pc pcf w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> <span class="ff3"> </span> <span class="ff8"> </span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">285</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsce">we know little about the internal three-dimensional structure of these parallel</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">fibril arrays at the level of crystal layers and fibril organization.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4f">The highly anisotropic structure of parallel fibril arrays has the obvious ad-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws85">vantage that they can be aligned in specific directions to optimize their me-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">chanical functions.<span class="_ _4"> </span>The attachment of a tendon to a bone surface with the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10">contact zone stiffened by mineralization is a good example of this adapta-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws91">tion.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The elastic properties are optimized in a given direction, and the stiff-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd0">ening of the structure essentially fixes the orientation. Parallel-fibered bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">has a much higher modulus value (around 26 GPa) in the direction parallel to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">the axis of long bones, as compared with the orthogonal directions (around</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws43">11 GPa) (49) (Figure 2).<span class="_ _b"> </span>We noted above (Lev<span class="_ _2"></span>el 3) that Ziv et al (48) measured</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y104 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd1">Vickers microhardness of parallel-fibered bone on three orthogonal planes,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y105 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">with the highest values also being on the plane perpendicular to the fibril axes</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y106 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">(T in Figure 3<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>) and with different but lower v<span class="_ _2"></span>alues on the other orthogonal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y107 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">planes.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y14d ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P<span class="_ _2"></span>attern 2:<span class="_ _6"> </span>W<span class="_ _2"></span>oven Fiber Structure</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y14e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">This pattern is in many respects the antithesis of pattern 1.<span class="_ _4"> </span>The fibrils are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y14f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14">arranged into bundles, some with rather large diameters (up to 30 <span class="ff9 wsb1">μ</span>m) and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y150 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">many with much smaller diameters (51).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The fibril bundles are loosely packed</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y151 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsac">and poorly oriented, particularly in the case of the small-diameter bundles</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y152 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws91">(Figure 6<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>).<span class="_ _7"> </span>There is also a large proportion of non-collagenous material in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y153 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd2">woven bone (16,<span class="_ _9"></span>51).<span class="_ _4"> </span>T<span class="_ _2"></span>reatment of woven bone with NaOCl to remove the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y154 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd3">accessible organic material reveals a pattern of spherical mineral clusters, with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h17 y155 ff6 fs2 fc0 sc0 lsa wsd4">←−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−−</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y156 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd5">Figure 6<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Four of the most common fibril array patterns of or<span class="_ _2"></span>ganization.<span class="_ _8"> </span>SEM micrographs</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y157 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws76">of fractured surfaces and schematic illustrations (not drawn to scale) of the basic organizational</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y158 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd6">motifs. (<span class="ff5 ws3b">a</span><span class="wsd7">) Array of parallel fibrils.<span class="_ _b"> </span>SEM: mineralized turkey tendon (scale:<span class="_ _b"> </span>0.1 mm).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Schematic</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y159 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd8">illustration<span class="_ _9"></span>showing<span class="_ _9"> </span>the localizedorthotropic symmetryof afibril b<span class="_ _2"></span>undle. (<span class="ff5 ws3b">b<span class="ff4">)<span class="_ _3"> </span>Wov<span class="_ _2"></span>en<span class="_ _3"> </span>fiber<span class="_ _9"> </span>structure.</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15a ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd9">SEM: outer layer of a 19-week old human fetus femur. (Micrograph provided by X Su. Also</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15b ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsda">published in Reference 52.)<span class="_ _8"> </span>Schematic illustration showing fibril bundles with varying sized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15c ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdb">diameters arranged in different orientations.<span class="_ _5"> </span>(<span class="ff5 ws3b">c</span>) Plywood-like structure present in lamellar bone.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15d ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdc">SEM: fracture surface of a baboon tibia showing the prominent fourth (<span class="ff5">large arr<span class="_ _2"></span>owhead<span class="ff4">) and fifth</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15e ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3b">(<span class="ff5 wsdd">small arrowhead<span class="ff4">) sub-layers (63,<span class="_ _9"></span>72).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Schematic illustration showing the five sub-layer model</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y15f ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsde">described in (63) with sub-layers one (<span class="ff5">right hand side</span>), two, and three arbitrarily composed of one</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y160 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsdf">fibril layer each, whereas sub-layers four and five are composed of four fibril layers each.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Note that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y161 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse0">the fibrils in each layer are rotated relative to their neighbors (depicted by the change in direction</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y162 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse1">of the ellipsoid cross-section), following the rotated plywood model (67). (<span class="ff5 ls9">d</span>) Radial fibril arrays.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y163 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse2">SEM: human dentin fractured roughly parallel to the pulp cavity surface.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The tubules (<span class="ff5 ws3b">holes</span>) are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y164 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse3">surrounded by collagen fibrils that are all more or less in one plane.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Schematic illustration of the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y165 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse4">fibril bundles arranged in a plane perpendicular to the tubule long axis. Within the plane they have</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y166 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">no obvious preferred orientation.</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="8">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf10" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="10"><div class="pc pc10 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>  <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">286 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9b">little evidence of the mineralized collagen fibrils (16).<span class="_ _7"> </span>Thus both the matrix</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">and the mineral are disorganized.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">Su et al (52) recently revealed a degree of structural complexity<span class="_ _2"></span>, hithertofore</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">unrecognized in human fetal woven bone.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The initially formed layers of woven</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1c">bone are indeed disordered.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The extent of order in terms of fibril alignment,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">however<span class="_ _2"></span>, increases as the spaces between the initially formed layers are filled</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">in. Furthermore, the rate of mineralization is very rapid. Measurements of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc5">the microhardness and elastic modulus (4–17 GPa) of these layers using a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">nanoindenter<span class="_ _9"></span>reflect<span class="_ _3"> </span>this<span class="_ _3"> </span>mineralization<span class="_ _9"></span>process<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>older<span class="_ _3"> </span>specimens<span class="_ _3"> </span>show</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws62">clear<span class="_ _3"></span>anisotropy<span class="_ _9"></span>when<span class="_ _3"> </span>comparing<span class="_ _3"> </span>cross-<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>longitudinal-sections. Woven<span class="_ _9"></span>fiber</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">structure may well be disordered as compared with other structural patterns at</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">this level, but this disorder does not result in isotropic properties.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbc">W<span class="_ _2"></span>oven bone is common in the skeletons of amphibia and reptiles, as well</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">as in the skeleton of the mammalian embryo (51).<span class="_ _7"> </span>During development, the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">latter is replaced by other bone types.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Embryonic woven bone is probably not</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse5">weight-bearing (except for gravity).<span class="_ _b"> </span>It is also formed relatively rapidly.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Wov<span class="_ _2"></span>en</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse6">bone is also the first bone type to be formed after fracture or in other pathologic</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">circumstances, i.e.<span class="_ _5"> </span>situations in which rapid formation is a prime concern.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y167 ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P<span class="_ _2"></span>attern 3:<span class="_ _6"> </span>Plywood-Like Structures</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc9">This pattern is characterized by sets of parallel fibrils and/or fiber bundles</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">present in discrete layers, with the fibril orientation in each layer being different</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscd">(Figure 6<span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The analogy of this bone structure type to plywood was first made</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsce">by W<span class="_ _2"></span>eiss & Ferris (53).<span class="_ _7"> </span>The analogy to laminated composites is also evident</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">(54).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y110 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">Plywood-like structural motifs are very common in nature and present a fas-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y111 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">cinating variety of numerical puzzles, each of which probably has an insightful</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y112 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws89">structure-function relation.<span class="_ _8"> </span>Bouligand (55) and Giraud-Guille (56) have not</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y113 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws22">only enumerated many of these structures, but have also pointed out some of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y114 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">the structural misinterpretations that arise when oblique sections through these</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y115 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">structures are studied.<span class="_ _5"> </span>In certain bone types, for example, this led to the incor-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y116 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">rect proposal that collagen fibrils have arc-like curvatures (57).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y117 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">The simplest plywood-like structure encountered in the bone family of ma-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y118 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws95">terials has parallel fibril arrays oriented orthogonally to each other in alternate</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y119 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">layers.<span class="_ _5"> </span>This motif occurs frequently in certain fish scales, many of which (but</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">not all) are fully mineralized (58). It is also the basic structural pattern of ce-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc1">mentum, the material that bonds tooth dentin to the jaw bone (59).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Orthogonal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">plywood was first reported to be present in lamellar bone by Gebhardt in 1906</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">(60).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Closer examination of the structure reveals far more complexity. In lamel-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse8">lar<span class="_ _9"></span>bone,<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>thicknesses<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>all<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>layers<span class="_ _3"> </span>are<span class="_ _3"></span>not<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>same. A<span class="_ _3"> </span>thin<span class="_ _9"></span>layer<span class="_ _3"> </span>or<span class="_ _3"> </span>lamella</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsce">is often followed by a thick one (61).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Thus a pair of such thin/thick lamellae</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="8">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf11" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="11"><div class="pc pc11 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   <span class="ff3"> <span class="ff2"> </span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">287</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">constitutes the basic repeating unit.<span class="_ _5"> </span>More careful examination of the plywood</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws47">structures of such lamellar units in human bone revealed that there is a tran-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">sition zone between the thin and thick lamellae (62).<span class="_ _6"> </span>In many lamellar bones</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">this transition zone is fairly well developed, and it is clear that the structure is</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws23">not composed of simple orthogonal plywood-like material.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Giraud-Guille (57)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">analyzed the structures of these more complex plywood patterns and showed</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">that the fibril arrays in successive layers progress from one direction through</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">intermediate angles to the orthogonal direction.<span class="_ _5"> </span>She referred to these structures</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">as twisted plywood.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws29">W<span class="_ _2"></span>einer et al (63) made a detailed study of collagen organization in the lamel-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5f">lar bone from rat femurs, using cryomicrotomed and vitrified thin sections (64)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y104 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse9">of demineralized material cut parallel to the lamellar boundary.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This prepa-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y105 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsad">ration procedure avoids the inevitable tissue distortion due to dehydration and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y106 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">hence the difficulty of interpreting obliquely cut sections.<span class="_ _5"> </span>They observed that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y107 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsea">successive layers of parallel fibrils in a thin/thick lamellar unit processed by</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h18 y108 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wseb">an angle of roughly 30<span class="ff6 fs3 lsb v2">◦</span><span class="v0">from one layer to the next.<span class="_ _7"> </span>They proposed a model</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y168 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">in which a lamellar unit is composed of five such sub-layers (Figure 6<span class="ff5 ws4">c</span><span class="wsec">). The</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h19 y169 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">fact that there are five and not six sub-layers oriented progressively e<span class="_ _2"></span>very 30<span class="ff6 fs3 ls7 v2">◦</span><span class="v0">,</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7e">means that the lamellar unit structure is not symmetrical (65).<span class="_ _7"> </span>Comparisons</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">of lamellar bone from different animals showed that in some cases sub-layers</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16">one and four were thicker than the others, giving rise to the overall appear-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">ance of a thin/thick orthogonal lamellar unit structure.<span class="_ _5"> </span>In other cases, however<span class="_ _2"></span>,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">the five sub-layers are roughly of equal thickness, giving the impression of a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y16f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2b">continuous structure, more analogous to twisted plywood (63).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Although not</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y170 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">enough information is currently available on the generality of the five sub-layer</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y171 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscb">lamellar unit model, it conceptually offers a synthesis for all lamellar bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y172 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">types described.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The main variable in terms of collagen fibrils is the different</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y173 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsee">thicknesses of the sub-layers, rather than the angle of procession from one layer</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y174 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws27">to the next.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Note, however, that not all in<span class="_ _2"></span>vestigators of the lamellar structure</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y175 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7c">concur with the Gebhardt plywood model.<span class="_ _5"> </span>See Marotti (66) for an alternative</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y176 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">model.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y177 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">The plywood pattern of lamellar bone incorporates another “novel” (for the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y178 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">world of synthetic materials) structural feature.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The fibril arrays that make up</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y179 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsef">one sub-layer of the lamellar unit also have an internal crystalline or three-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">dimensional structure (Level 2).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Examination of the orientations of the crystal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsca">layers within each of the sub-layers reveals a progressiv<span class="_ _2"></span>e rotation from the first</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf0">sub-layer adjacent to the lamellar boundary, where the crystal layers appear</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws13">to be parallel to the boundary, to the fourth and fifth sub-layers, where they</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbf">are at a high angle to the boundary. W<span class="_ _2"></span>einer et al (67) therefore referred to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y17f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">this as rotated plywood (Figure 6<span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>).<span class="_ _5"> </span>Unfortunately, it has not been possible to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y180 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1b">accurately measure the rotation angles.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Note that as the rotation is always in</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="9">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf12" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="12"><div class="pc pc12 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   <span class="ff3"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">288 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">one direction, this results in a lamellar unit being asymmetric—an important</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4c">point<span class="_ _9"></span>when<span class="_ _3"> </span>considering<span class="_ _3"> </span>its<span class="_ _3"> </span>mechanical<span class="_ _3"> </span>behavior. Such<span class="_ _9"></span>structures<span class="_ _3"> </span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>fascinating</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8e">for scientists and engineers who usually design composite materials containing</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf1">single fibers or fiber bundles that have radial symmetry<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _8"> </span>Layers of platelets</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws54">within the fibril do not have radial symmetry<span class="_ _2"></span>, and thus an additional degree</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">of freedom is introduced.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This could be used for tailoring purposes.<span class="_ _7"> </span>Recent</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">model studies deal with such problems in some detail (29,<span class="_ _3"></span>68,<span class="_ _9"></span>69).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb3">Lamellar bone may appear to be the ultimate in structural sophistication</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc4">when it comes to plywood patterns. It is probably not. Consider the pattern of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9c">the unmineralized scale of the primitive coelacanth fish (70). A detailed and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">insightful analysis of the successive orientations of the fibril orientations from</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">layer to layer shows that in every pair of layers the fibrils are orthogonally ori-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">ented and that in successive pairs the orientations rotate progressively in a gi<span class="_ _2"></span>ven</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">direction. In fact, if every alternate layer is regarded as a set, then the angular</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">progression<span class="_ _9"></span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>regular.<span class="_ _9"></span>It<span class="_ _3"> </span>would<span class="_ _3"> </span>be<span class="_ _3"> </span>fascinating<span class="_ _3"> </span>to<span class="_ _3"> </span>understand<span class="_ _3"></span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>mechanical<span class="_ _9"></span>pro-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">perties of the scale in relation to its structure. The elastic properties could possi-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscb">bly be modeled by means of conventional laminate analysis (54), but other</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">properties such as strength and toughness are more difficult to understand.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y3c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws50">Lamellar bone with its rotated plywood structure is very common, especially</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf2">in mammals, and is the most common bone type in humans. Thus from an</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">anthropomorphic point of view it is very important.<span class="_ _5"> </span>However<span class="_ _2"></span>, it is difficult to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws24">study the mechanical properties of the structure per se because planar arrays</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y40 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">of lamellae are not generally available in the sizes required for standard tests</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y41 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">(<span class="ff6 wsb2">≈</span><span class="ws4c">15 mm <span class="ff6 ls6">×</span><span class="lsc wsf4">1m<span class="_ _a"></span>m<span class="ff6 ls6">×</span><span class="ls2 wsc6">1 mm). What is generally available in these sizes are</span></span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y42 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">lamellae<span class="_ _9"></span>folded<span class="_ _3"> </span>into<span class="_ _3"></span>cylinders<span class="_ _9"></span>(osteons;<span class="_ _3"> </span>see<span class="_ _3"> </span>Level<span class="_ _9"></span>5),<span class="_ _3"> </span>or<span class="_ _3"></span>sausage-shaped<span class="_ _9"></span>lamellar</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y43 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">cylinders in parallel-fibered bone.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y44 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws63">Ziv et al (48) measured the microhardness values of planar circumferential</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf5">lamellar bone from the rat tibia in many different orientations with respect to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">the rotated plywood structure.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The results clearly reveal anisotropy, with the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y60 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">highest values found in the plane perpendicular to the long axis of the bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y61 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws84">(around 830 MPa) and lower values in the orthogonal planes (685–735 MP<span class="_ _2"></span>a).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y62 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">However<span class="_ _2"></span>, the extent of anisotropy is much less when compared with parallel-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y63 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">fibered bone of similar mineral content.<span class="_ _5"> </span>This implies that the rotated plywood</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y181 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6d">structure results in a material that is more isotropic than the building block from</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y182 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbc">which it is constructed, an important strategy adopted by this material.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y183 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd3">in turn may reflect the requirement for lamellar bone to withstand compressive</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y184 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf7">forces in many directions, unlike parallel-fibered bone, which is optimized</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y185 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscf">in one direction.<span class="_ _4"> </span>The microhardness study also rev<span class="_ _2"></span>ealed the asymmetry of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y186 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws64">the rotated plywood structure, raising the fundamental mechanical question</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y187 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws16">of how this asymmetry does not result in the weakening of the structure by</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y188 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">buckling.</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="9">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf13" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="13"><div class="pc pc13 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x3 y189 w7 h1a lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/19.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">  <span class="ff3"> </span> <span class="ff2">  </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">289</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y18a ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws58">Figure 7<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Plots of the flexural modulus and nominal w<span class="_ _2"></span>ork-to-fracture of baboon tibia (<span class="ff5 ws3b">a</span>) planar</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y18b ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf8">(circumferential) lamellar bone and (<span class="ff5 ws3b">b</span>) osteonal bone versus orientation of the specimen relative</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y18c ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf9">to the whole bone long axis.<span class="_ _5"> </span>0<span class="ff6 fs8 ls7 v2">◦</span><span class="v0">—the long axis of the specimen is parallel to the long axis of the</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h1b y18d ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfa">bone; 90<span class="ff6 fs8 ls7 v2">◦</span><span class="wsfb v0">—the long axis of the specimen is perpendicular to the bone long axis.<span class="_ _b"> </span>In all cases, stress</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y18e ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws57">was applied perpendicular to the natural bone outer surface and the measurements were made in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y18f ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">the three-point bending mode.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Data from Liu et al (72).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y10b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws63">An invaluable opportunity to study planar arrays of lamellar bone in three-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">point<span class="_ _3"></span>bending<span class="_ _3"></span>arose<span class="_ _3"></span>when<span class="_ _3"></span>a<span class="_ _3"> </span>section<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>baboon<span class="_ _3"> </span>tibia<span class="_ _3"> </span>(following<span class="_ _9"></span>treatment<span class="_ _b"> </span>with<span class="_ _9"></span>an</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc1">anti-osteoporotic drug, alendronate) (71) was found to have extensi<span class="_ _2"></span>ve volumes</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws82">of circumferential lamellar bone (72).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Specimens were examined in four differ-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfc">ent orientations relative to the bone long axis and were clearly anisotropic with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y110 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">respect to the flexural modulus, bending strength, fracture strain, and nominal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y111 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfd">work-to-fracture.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The highest values were always obtained when the loading</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y112 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">axis was perpendicular to the long axis of the bone, namely in the direction in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y113 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsaa">which the greatest compressive forces are normally applied in this bone.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y114 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws79">extent of anisotropy for the flexural modulus is around 1.8 (the ratio in the two</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y115 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">orthogonal directions), whereas for the nominal work-to-fracture it is as large</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y116 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws34">as 22 (Figure 7<span class="ff5 ws4">a</span>).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The structure has somehow resulted in the ultimate proper-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y117 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4b">ties being very anisotropic and distinctly favorable for the direction in which</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y118 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6c">most natural challenges to the bone will occur vis-a-vis fracture, namely with</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y119 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9f">stress being applied perpendicular to the bone long axis. When this occurs, the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf6">fracture plane is tortuous, with the crack following either the lamellar bound-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">ary planes or the plane perpendicular to the natural surface.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The latter fracture</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfe">surface is almost featureless and resembles a ceramic (Figure 8<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>).<span class="_ _6"> </span>In the un-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">natural situation, when the long axis of the specimen is orthogonal to the bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf0">long axis, the fracture plane reveals the lamellar structure (Figure 8<span class="ff5 ws4">a</span><span class="wsff">). The</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">challenge now is to relate both the elastic and the ultimate properties of planar</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="10">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf14" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="14"><div class="pc pc14 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x3 y190 w8 h1c lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/20.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span> <span class="ff3"> </span> <span class="ff2">  </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">290 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y191 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws100">Figure 8<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">SEM electron micrographs of the surfaces of planar (circumferential) lamellar baboon</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y192 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">tibia bone after fracture in (<span class="ff5 ws3b">a</span><span class="lsd ws101">)9<span class="_ _2"></span>0</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x15 h1d y193 ff6 fs8 fc0 sc0 lse">◦<span class="ff4 fs1 ls2 ws0 v3">orientation, and (<span class="ff5 ws3b">b<span class="ff4 lsd">)0</span></span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x16 h1d y193 ff6 fs8 fc0 sc0 lse">◦<span class="ff4 fs1 ls2 ws0 v3">orientation (see Figure 7).</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y194 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">arrays of lamellar bone to its structure.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The gaps in our current understanding</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y195 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws102">of the structure, especially of the lamellar boundaries themselves, preclude a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y196 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">comprehensive analysis.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y197 ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P<span class="_ _2"></span>attern 4:<span class="_ _6"> </span>Radial Fibril Arrays</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">This pattern is characteristic of the bulk of dentin, the material that forms the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y198 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws103">inner layer of teeth.<span class="_ _8"> </span>The collagen fibrils are almost all in the plane parallel</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y199 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws104">to the surface at which dentin formation takes place in the pulp cavity (73).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y19a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4a">Within this plane, howev<span class="_ _2"></span>er, the fibril bundles are for the most part randomly</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y19b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">to poorly oriented, depending on the specific tooth and the location within the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y19c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">tooth (Figure 6<span class="ff5 lsf">d</span>).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y19d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9e">The<span class="_ _3"></span>crystal<span class="_ _3"> </span>organization<span class="_ _3"></span>follows<span class="_ _9"></span>two<span class="_ _3"> </span>quite<span class="_ _b"> </span>distinct<span class="_ _9"></span>patterns: (<span class="ff5 ws4">a<span class="ff4">)<span class="_ _b"> </span>Within<span class="_ _9"></span>colla-</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y19e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsba">gen fibrils in dentin, <span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>-axes are oriented parallel to the fibril long axes (74), and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y19f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">the crystals are in layers across the fibril (75).<span class="_ _5"> </span>(<span class="ff5 ws4">b</span>) In loci presumably between</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws105">fibrils, the crytals have a random orientation and/or radiate out from the center</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8f">of a locus (41, 76). In human root dentin, there is a preferred <span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>-axis orientation</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws106">in the collagen fibril plane, but there are also many crystals with <span class="ff5 ws4">c</span>-axes oriented</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws48">in all directions.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This is presumably the result of both crystal organizational</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">types being more or less equally represented (77).<span class="_ _6"> </span>Furthermore, TEM obser-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">vations of bundles of collagen fibrils show that the crystal layers are not al<span class="_ _2"></span>ways</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">aligned between neighboring fibrils (75).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y1a7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws107">Dentin structure is therefore highly anisotropic because the collagen fibrils</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">are essentially confined to one plane.<span class="_ _7"> </span>In terms of crystal organization, how-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1a9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws23">ever<span class="_ _2"></span>, the extent of anisotropy is much less. Other highly anisotropic features of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1aa ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11">dentin are the tubules, which pass through the structure from the pulp cavity</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1ab ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsad">to the region close to the dentin-enamel junction (Figure 6<span class="ff5 lsf">d</span>). These holes oc-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1ac ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws98">cupy about 10% or less by volume of the bulk dentin and are oriented roughly</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="10">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf15" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="15"><div class="pc pc15 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0"> <span class="ff2"> </span>   </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">291</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">perpendicular to the collagen fibril plane.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Therefore, it is surprising that stud-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">ies of the elastic modulus of dentin have revealed no significant anisotrop<span class="_ _2"></span>y in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws108">relation to the structure (78, 79).<span class="_ _b"> </span>This could, in part, be due to the difficulties of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">testing such small specimens.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Studies of dentin microhardness do reveal signif-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9f">icant variations between locations on one plane within the tooth (78).<span class="_ _b"> </span>Because</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsbc">of this variation, detection of anisotropy in dentin using microhardness must</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws70">be made at one specific location.<span class="_ _5"> </span>W<span class="_ _2"></span>ang & Weiner (75) performed such tests on</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws15">human dentin sectioned in different directions and confirmed that dentin is es-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc2">sentially isotropic. In structural terms, we suspect that the essentially isotropic</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wseb">elastic and hardness properties are derived mostly from the crystal organiza-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yca ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws42">tion.<span class="_ _5"> </span>We note that there is a lar<span class="_ _2"></span>ge proportion of essentially unoriented crystals</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y104 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">and that even in fibril bundles, the crystal layers of neighboring fibrils are not</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y105 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws105">aligned.<span class="_ _5"> </span>It is also noteworthy that in contrast to the elastic properties, the frac-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y106 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws51">ture properties of dentin are anisotropic, with the crack preferably following</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y107 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">the plane in which the mineralized collagen fibrils are present (80).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y1ad ff5 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Mechanical Implications</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1ae ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws78">Level 4 structural organization is in many respects the heart of the subject.<span class="_ _5"> </span>It</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1af ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6f">is at this level that structural div<span class="_ _2"></span>ersity would appear to be optimized to func-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws44">tional need. W<span class="_ _2"></span>e can surmise that mineralized tendons are strong in tension,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsea">lamellar bone is built to withstand stresses in many directions, and dentin is</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb0">structured to withstand compressive forces in one prev<span class="_ _2"></span>ailing direction,<span class="_ _6"> </span>and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws61">so on. Nonetheless, it is evident that serious gaps in our knowledge exist,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">both with respect to data on the micromechanical properties of these materials</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">(aside from hardness) and in terms of understanding the structure. One reason</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws84">for the former is the difficulty in acquiring large enough samples of the mate-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws88">rial comprised only of the particular structural type of interest for mechanical</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b8 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2f">testing. W<span class="_ _2"></span>e suspect that the enormous natural diversity in this family of ma-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1b9 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsef">terials has not been thoroughly explored and that suitable materials may be</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1ba ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">available, albeit from exotic sources. With good data in hand on structure and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1bb ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws5f">mechanical properties, the problem of relating structure to function will be less</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1bc ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2">formidable.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y1bd ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 5:<span class="_ _5"> </span>CYLINDRICAL MOTIFS—OSTEONS</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1be ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws24">Bones themselves, as opposed to dentin, cementum, scales, and most miner-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1bf ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">alized tendons, often undergo internal remodeling.<span class="_ _6"> </span>This process involves the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1c0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc1">excavating out of large tunnels by teams of specialized cells called osteoclasts.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1c1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws109">These tunnels are then refilled by osteoblasts, starting with the deposition of a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1c2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws41">thin layer of cement on the existing excavated surf<span class="_ _2"></span>ace, followed by layers of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1c3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb5">lamellar bone. The process stops when the tunnel is almost completely filled,</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

                                            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="11">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf16" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="16"><div class="pc pc16 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   <span class="ff3"> <span class="ff2"> </span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">292 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10a">leaving a narrow channel at the center that functions as a blood vessel (5)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">(Figure 1; Level 5).<span class="_ _5"> </span>In fact, other even smaller capillary-like features (canali-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">culi) are also built into the structure.<span class="_ _b"> </span>These canaliculi are numerous and house</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">the cells (osteocytes) that remain within the bone material itself.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The canaliculi</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">tend to radiate out from the central blood vessel.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Thus the structure of an osteon</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wseb">is basically onion-like in cross-section with layers of lamellae surrounding a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">central hole; in longitudinal section they are cylindrical (Figure 1; Level 5).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">The osteon also contains many elongated pores.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">A brief note on confusing terminology (5):<span class="_ _5"> </span>The osteonal structures are also</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb5">called Haversian systems, erroneously named after John Havers who actually</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa9">discovered the lamellae in 1691 (81).<span class="_ _b"> </span>van Leeuwenhoek discovered the osteons</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws35">in 1693 (82).<span class="_ _5"> </span>These structures are also often referred to as secondary osteons to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">differentiate them from similarly shaped structures that are laid down de nov<span class="_ _2"></span>o,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws83">e.g.<span class="_ _b"> </span>in the spaces between the parallel-fibered bone in fibrolamellar (plexiform)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">bone (50).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10b">The widespread phenomenon of remodeling is itself a good indication that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd3">it must be important.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Despite the hundreds of years that have elapsed since the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws49">osteons were identified, we do not have a complete understanding of the advan-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws84">tages, including possible mechanical benefits, that this process affords.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Many</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">studies have compared the mechanical properties of secondary osteonal bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">with primary bone (83,<span class="_ _3"></span>84).<span class="_ _5"> </span>The primary bone usually used was fibrolamellar</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">(plexiform) bone, which is comprised of both parallel-fibered bone and primary</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y40 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws66">osteons.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Secondary osteonal bone composed of cylindrical arrays of lamellae</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y41 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws33">should be compared with primary lamellar bone comprised of planar arrays of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y42 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc4">lamellae.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The latter, as noted above, is not naturally available in lar<span class="_ _2"></span>ge enough</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y43 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">quantities for standard mechanical tests.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Liu et al (72), however<span class="_ _2"></span>, recently stud-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y44 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws104">ied such planar lamellar arrays in an unnatural bone produced as a result of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb4">treatment by alendronate and have compared it to osteonal bone taken from the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">same baboon tibia, albeit from the opposing side of the mid-shaft.<span class="_ _6"> </span>Figure 7<span class="ff5">b</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y60 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf1">shows the results for the flexural modulus and the nominal work-to-fracture</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y61 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10b">in four different orientations of osteonal bone.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The basic trends and absolute</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y62 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10c">values are similar to those of planar lamellar bone (Figure 7<span class="ff5 ws4">a</span>), except for the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y63 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws89">off-axis values, where in the latter, the differences between the curv<span class="_ _2"></span>es are a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y181 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws45">little larger than the on-axis values.<span class="_ _b"> </span>It is difficult to definitively ascribe this dif-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y182 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa6">ference to a particular aspect of the rotated plywood structure, but it may well</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y183 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">be related to the presence of a prominent fifth sub-lamella in the lamellar unit</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h1e y184 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">of baboon tibia that is oriented 30<span class="ff6 fs3 ls10 v2">◦</span><span class="v0">from the bone long axis (Figure 6<span class="ff5 ws4">c</span><span class="ws10d">). This</span></span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y66 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">asymmetry would be canceled out in a cylindrical structure (Figure 9).<span class="_ _b"> </span>In fact,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y67 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscc">this canceling out effect of the asymmetry due to the folding of the lamellae into</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y68 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws105">cylinders may well be one of the important mechanical advantages of osteonal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y69 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws8e">bone over bone composed of planar lamellar arrays.<span class="_ _b"> </span>In general, however, it can</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>

<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">293</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y1c5 ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10e">Figure 9<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4">Schematic illustration (not drawn to scale) of a c<span class="_ _2"></span>ylindrical osteon-like structure with the</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y1c6 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws93">five sub-lamellar model superimposed.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The orientation of the sub-layers is reversed on opposite</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y1c7 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse4">sides of the cylinder, thus balancing the asymmetry of the lamellar structure. Figure from Liu et al</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y1c8 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2">(72).</div>

                                    <div id="pf18" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="18"><div class="pc pc18 w0 h0"><div class="pdf-bg bi x18 y1c9 wa h20 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Daniel-Wagner-28/publication/234151607/viewer/AS:131044607008768@1408254878013/background/24.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
<div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">   <span class="ff3"> </span> <span class="ff2"> </span></div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">294 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h21 y1ca ff5 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws10f">Figure 10<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff4 ws110">Flexural stress-strain curv<span class="_ _2"></span>es of baboon tibia measured in three-point bending at 0<span class="fs8 ls11 v2">o</span>and</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h1b y1cb ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws3b">90<span class="ff6 fs8 ls12 v2">◦</span><span class="ws111 v0">(see Figure 7).<span class="_ _b"> </span>The heavy lines are for planar (circumferential) lamellar bone and the thin lines</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h3 y1cc ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">for osteonal bone.<span class="_ _b"> </span>Data from Liu et al (72).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y47 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">be concluded that the elastic properties are mostly due to the lamellar structure</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y48 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">itself and not to the folding of lamellae into cylinders.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y49 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse8">This<span class="_ _9"></span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>not<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"></span>case<span class="_ _9"></span>for<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>ultimate<span class="_ _3"> </span>properties. A<span class="_ _9"></span>comparison<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>typical<span class="_ _3"> </span>sets<span class="_ _3"></span>of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">stress-strain<span class="_ _3"></span>curves<span class="_ _9"></span>for<span class="_ _3"> </span>planar<span class="_ _3"> </span>lamellar<span class="_ _3"> </span>arrays<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>cylindrical<span class="_ _3"> </span>lamellar<span class="_ _3"> </span>structures</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws38">(Figure 10), shows obvious differences in the fracture behavior<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _6"> </span>The osteonal</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">bone reveals far more damage-related features and a pronounced tailing effect</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws47">(72).<span class="_ _7"> </span>The latter is related to the observation that following massive fracture,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa7">the two pieces of the osteonal bone always remain attached, whereas the planar</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y4f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">lamellar bone fractures cleanly into two halves.<span class="_ _8"> </span>This may afford important</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y50 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws112">biological benefits.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The natural wound healing process of a fractured bone can</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y51 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">only<span class="_ _9"></span>take<span class="_ _3"> </span>place<span class="_ _3"> </span>if<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>two<span class="_ _9"></span>segments<span class="_ _3"> </span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>in<span class="_ _3"> </span>close<span class="_ _3"></span>proximity. Otherwise<span class="_ _9"></span>a<span class="_ _3"></span>so-called</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y52 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws97">non-union fracture occurs that will heal only with surgical intervention.<span class="_ _b"> </span>There</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y53 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6e">may well be other, yet to be discovered, mechanical benefits of osteonal bone</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y54 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf">compared with planar arrays of lamellae.<span class="_ _5"> </span>In principle, it is possible to predict</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
