            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="12">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf19" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="19"><div class="pc pc19 w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">    </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x11 h4 y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">BONE, THE MA<span class="_ _2"></span>TERIAL<span class="_ _1"> </span><span class="fs2">295</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">the elastic constants of osteons or arrays of osteons, using Lekhnitskii’s work</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb6">on fully orthotropic solids (85).<span class="_ _7"> </span>Although algebraically difficult, this should</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws11">be feasible, providing the data for the basic physical parameters (the relative</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsfc">weight or volume content, the various elastic constants of the components, etc)</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 yc4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">are available.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y1cd ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">LEVEL 6:<span class="_ _5"> </span>SOLID VERSUS SPONGY BONE,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y1ce ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">AND LEVEL 7:<span class="_ _5"> </span>WHOLE BONES</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1cf ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">Figure 1, Level 6, is a photograph of spongy bone associated with solid or com-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d0 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsba">pact bone.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Figure 1, Level 7, is a photograph of a whole bone.<span class="_ _b"> </span>A vast literature</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d1 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb8">exists on both subjects (e.g.<span class="_ _5"> </span>4), which relates the mechanical properties to the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d2 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">material bone, as well as to their overall structures and shapes.<span class="_ _b"> </span>This is beyond</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7a">the scope of this review<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _7"> </span>For an overview of the subject, readers are referred</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d4 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws53">to Currey (2), and for a more biological perspective to Martin & Burr (5). For</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d5 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws113">a fascinating as well as historical view<span class="_ _2"></span>, the chapter on bone in Thompson’s</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d6 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">classic book is recommended (86).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h9 y10a ff4 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">CONCLUDING COMMENTS</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws31">Progress is being made on understanding the structure-mechanical function re-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">lations in the bone family of materials.<span class="_ _5"> </span>Although many gaps in our knowledge</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws60">exist, especially when the structure is considered in terms of its 7 hierarchical</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws2a">levels, our theoretical understanding of these relations and predictive capabili-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y10f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws7d">ties are slowly impro<span class="_ _2"></span>ving.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The more we learn, the more we realize that<span class="_ _9"></span>there are</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y110 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wscc">striking similarities between bone and man-made polymers and composites and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y111 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws108">that materials sciences can benefit from the basic work that has been performed</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y112 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9c">in<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"> </span>field<span class="_ _9"></span>and<span class="_ _3"> </span>vice<span class="_ _3"> </span>versa. Simple<span class="_ _9"></span>examples<span class="_ _3"> </span>are<span class="_ _3"> </span>the<span class="_ _9"></span>high-molecular-weight</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y113 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc4">organic fibers such as aramids (Kevlar) or polyethylene. They are structurally</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y114 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">organized like tendons, from the molecular level up. In both the biological and</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y115 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">the synthetic materials, the structural and evidently mechanical anisotropies</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y116 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12">are highest at the molecular scale, but are progressively reduced as the scale</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y117 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws52">increases through sub-fibrillar and fibrillar arrays, up to the micrometer level</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y118 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsad">(the single fiber).<span class="_ _5"> </span>At higher levels, both bone and man-made composites have</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y119 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">structures and physical properties that show progressively less anisotropy<span class="_ _2"></span>.<span class="_ _5"> </span>This</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsab">occurs, for example, when large arrays of single fiber-based plies or lamel-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">lae are arranged into layered or laminated structures at various angles.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">is an important characteristic of structural design in nature and synthetically</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws28">by humans, which in both cases is motivated by the fact that complex macro-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1d">scopic structures are usually not designed uniquely for a single type of stress,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y11f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws19">but rather against stresses of various types, applied in various directions.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>
<div class="t m1 xb hb y28 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">by WEIZMANN INST.OF SCIENCE on 08/23/05. For personal use only.</div>
</div>
<div class="pi" data-data='{"ctm":[1.601307,0.000000,0.000000,1.601307,-116.895425,-187.352941]}'></div>
</div>

                                            <div class="pdf-page-separator"></div>

            <div class="pdf-viewer-page js-lazy-load-page" data-lazy-batch="13">
                                    <div class="pdf-lazy-load">
                                    <div id="pf1a" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="1a"><div class="pc pc1a w0 h0"><div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">     </div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h3 y2 ff4 fs1 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">P1: ARS/spd/dsi<span class="_ _0"> </span>P2: ARS/dat<span class="_ _0"> </span>QC: ARS/tkj<span class="_ _0"> </span>T1: NBL</div>
<div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">May 13, 1998<span class="_ _1"> </span>12:44<span class="_ _1"> </span>Annual Reviews<span class="_ _1"> </span>AR059-11</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y29 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws18">296 <span class="fs6 ws0">WEINER & W<span class="_ _2"></span>AGNER</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">design criteria, therefore, are varied rather than single-valued, and structural</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws114">complexity is unavoidable.<span class="_ _8"> </span>This effect also results in the gradual loss of a</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws71">formal link between the various physical properties at higher and higher orga-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc3">nizational levels.<span class="_ _b"> </span>For example, by using a scaled-up<span class="_ _9"></span>model it may be possible to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wse7">predict the stiffness of a fibril based on that of a single molecule, but it is much</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y2f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws81">more difficult to predict the stiffness of a macroscopic composite structure from</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y30 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wseb">the stiffness of a molecule.<span class="_ _7"> </span>The prediction of strength is even more difficult</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y31 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">because of the higher sensitivity of that property to the presence of defects.</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y32 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws37">Extensive work has been performed in the field of composite materials to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y33 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws65">predict elastic constants, mostly of complex laminated structures in planar or</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y34 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws12">cylindrical form; e.g.<span class="_ _7"> </span>see the laminate theory in Reference 54.<span class="_ _7"> </span>In principle,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y35 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6b">rather complex cases such as the predictions of the elastic constants of osteons</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y36 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsce">or arrays of osteons may also be dealt with using Lekhnitskii’s work on fully</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y37 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4d">orthotropic solids (85).<span class="_ _5"> </span>We wish to emphasize, ho<span class="_ _2"></span>wever, that especially in the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y38 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsc8">case of biological materials and structures, models can only lead to simplified</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y39 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">results,<span class="_ _3"></span>in<span class="_ _9"></span>view<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _9"></span>the<span class="_ _3"> </span>inherent<span class="_ _3"> </span>variability<span class="_ _9"></span>of<span class="_ _3"> </span>material<span class="_ _3"> </span>and<span class="_ _3"></span>geometrical<span class="_ _9"></span>properties,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws80">the aging effects, and our current lack of detailed information of the structures</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsd2">and the properties at the smaller scales.<span class="_ _8"> </span>In the case of bone,<span class="_ _5"> </span>this structural</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws115">complexity<span class="_ _9"></span>appears<span class="_ _b"> </span>in<span class="_ _9"></span>various<span class="_ _3"> </span>often<span class="_ _3"> </span>subtle<span class="_ _3"> </span>forms. One<span class="_ _3"> </span>important<span class="_ _3"> </span>example<span class="_ _3"> </span>is<span class="_ _3"> </span>the</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsae">interplay of fibrils and laminates at all levels.<span class="_ _b"> </span>The power of theoretical models</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa5">to bridge gaps in our knowledge is possibly the greatest at the level of the single</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y3f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws6c">lamella or of the parallel fibrillar arrays, and it is precisely at these levels that</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y40 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa2">experimental results are still lacking, due<span class="_ _9"></span>to the technical difficulties in<span class="_ _2"></span>volved in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y41 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws26">testing<span class="_ _9"></span>very<span class="_ _3"> </span>small<span class="_ _3"> </span>specimens. Models<span class="_ _3"> </span>for<span class="_ _3"> </span>bone<span class="_ _3"></span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>various<span class="_ _9"></span>degrees<span class="_ _3"> </span>of<span class="_ _3"></span>complexity</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y42 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws1f">have indeed been proposed over the years, based mostly on concepts de<span class="_ _2"></span>veloped</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y43 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws17">in the field of composite materials (29,<span class="_ _3"></span>49, 87–93).<span class="_ _8"> </span>However<span class="_ _2"></span>, only a few of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y44 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">these models incorporate platelet-or ribbon-shaped reinforcement and take into</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb6">account some of the detailed geometrical and structural features (29,<span class="_ _3"></span>68,<span class="_ _9"></span>69).</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y5f ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">There is clearly a great need for additional careful experimental work with very</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y60 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">small specimens with well-defined structures (72,<span class="_ _3"></span>94).</div>
<div class="t m0 xc h4 y61 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsb9">The family of mineralized collagen-based materials presents a variety of</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y62 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4e">structures that represent solutions to demanding mechanical requirements.<span class="_ _5"> </span>The</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y63 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsed">study of the structure-mechanical function relations in such materials is a fasci-</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y181 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsa0">nating subject in its own right and may provide novel ideas that can be applied</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y182 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">to the improvement of synthetic materials.</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y1d7 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws4">A<span class="fs1 ws3b v0">CKNOWLEDGMENTS</span></div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y100 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wsf3">W<span class="_ _2"></span>e thank Lia Addadi, Udi Akiva, Talmon Arad, Danmei Liu, Ilana Sabanay<span class="_ _2"></span>,</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y101 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws9b">W<span class="_ _2"></span>olfie Traub, Rizhi Wang, and Vi<span class="_ _2"></span>vi Ziv for their invaluable contributions to</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y102 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws14">our knowledge of bone.<span class="_ _8"> </span>We also thank Shoshana Neumann for her help in</div>
<div class="t m0 x3 h4 y103 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls2 wseb">preparing this manuscript.<span class="_ _7"> </span>This study was supported by U.S. Public Service</div>
<div class="t m1 xa hb y27 ff7 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls2 ws0">Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci. 1998.28:271-298. Downloaded from arjournals.annualreviews.org</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Guoqi-Ni-2239692185" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Guoqi Ni</span></span></a></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Wei-Du-2269894265" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Wei Du</span></span></a></li>
</ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7ba214 lite-page-hidden">Reactive oxygen species (ROS) has great influence in many physiological or pathological processes in organisms. In the site of bone defects, the overproduced ROS significantly affects the dynamic balance process of bone regeneration. Many antioxidative organic and inorganic antioxidants showed good osteogenic ability, which has been widely used for bone repair. It is of great significance to summarize the antioxidative bone repair materials (ABRMs) to provide guidance for the future design and preparation of osteogenic materials with antioxidative function. Here, this review introduced the major research direction of ABRM at present in nanoscale, 2-dimensional coating, and 3-dimensional scaffolds. Moreover, the referring main active substances and antioxidative properties were classified, and the positive roles of antioxidative materials for bone repair have also been clearly summarized in signaling pathways, antioxidant enzymes, cellular responses and animal levels.</span></div>
</div>

<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7ba66b lite-page-hidden">Elephant ivory, a prestigious and valuable raw material in the post-Roman West and Byzantium between the 5th and 7th centuries AD, may originate from various sources. While both written and art historical evidence suggests that in the case of early medieval artefacts, African provenance is more likely than Asian, no data at hand is conclusive. The present paper investigates, with the help of FTIR and Raman spectroscopy, carbon and nitrogen concentration and nitrogen isotope (δ 15 N) analyses, the material resources of elephant ivory artefacts discovered in 6th- and 7th-century AD archaeological context in the Carpathian Basin to contribute to our understanding of late antique long-distance trade networks and economic relations.</span></div>
</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Han-Sung-Jung" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://c5.rgstatic.net/m/4671872220764/images/template/default/profile/profile_default_m.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Han-Sung Jung"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Han-Sung Jung</span></span></a></li>
</ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7bafba lite-page-hidden">Ameloblasts are specialized cells derived from the dental epithelium that produce enamel, a hierarchically structured tissue comprised of highly elongated hydroxylapatite (OHAp) crystallites. The unique function of the epithelial cells synthesizing crystallites and assembling them in a mechanically robust structure is not fully elucidated yet, partly due to limitations with in vitro experimental models. Herein, we demonstrate the ability to generate mineralizing dental epithelial organoids (DEOs) from adult dental epithelial stem cells (aDESCs) isolated from mouse incisor tissues. DEOs expressed ameloblast markers, could be maintained for more than five months (11 passages) in vitro in media containing modulators of Wnt, Egf, Bmp, Fgf and Notch signaling pathways, and were amenable to cryostorage. When transplanted underneath murine kidney capsules, organoids produced OHAp crystallites similar in composition, size, and shape to mineralized dental tissues, including some enamel-like elongated crystals. DEOs are thus a powerful in vitro model to study mineralization process by dental epithelium, which can pave the way to understanding amelogenesis and developing regenerative therapy of enamel.</span></div>
</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Arnaud-Bardouil-2175097011" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Arnaud Bardouil</span></span></a></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Nadine-Nassif-3" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/584668600619008-1516407265748_Q64/Nadine-Nassif-3.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Nadine Nassif"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Nadine Nassif</span></span></a></li>
</ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7bac6a lite-page-hidden">Bone is created by osteoblasts that secrete osteoid after which an ordered texture emerges, followed by mineralization. Plywood geometries are a hallmark of many trabecular and cortical bones, yet the origin of this texturing in vivo has never been shown. Nevertheless, extensive in vitro work revealed how plywood textures of fibrils can emerge from acidic molecular cholesteric collagen mesophases. This study demonstrates in sheep, which is the preferred model for skeletal research for orthopaedic research, that the deeper non‐fibrillar osteoid is organized in a liquid‐crystal cholesteric geometry. This basophilic domain, rich in acidic glycosaminoglycans, exhibits low pH which presumably fosters mesoscale collagen molecule ordering in vivo. The results suggest that the collagen fibril motif of twisted plywood matures slowly through self‐assembly thermodynamically driven processes as proposed by the Bouligand theory of biological analogues of liquid crystals. Understanding the steps of collagen patterning in osteoid‐maturation processes may shed new light on bone pathologies that emerge from collagen physico‐chemical maturation imbalances.</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Maria-Pau-Ginebra" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/979552029384710-1610554811749_Q64/Maria-Pau-Ginebra.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Maria-Pau Ginebra"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Maria-Pau Ginebra</span></span></a></li>
</ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7bb11e lite-page-hidden">Hydroxyapatite-based materials have been widely used in countless applications, such as bone regeneration, catalysis, air and water purification or protein separation. Recently, much interest has been given to controlling the aspect ratio of hydroxyapatite crystals from bulk samples. The ability to exert control over the aspect ratio may revolutionize the applications of these materials towards new functional materials. Controlling the shape, size and orientation of HA crystals allows obtaining high aspect ratio structures, improving several key properties of HA materials such as molecule adsorption, ion exchange, catalytic reactions, and even overcoming the well-known brittleness of ceramic materials. Regulating the morphogenesis of HA crystals to form elongated oriented fibres has led to flexible inorganic synthetic sponges, aerogels, membranes, papers, among others, with applications in sustainability, energy and catalysis, and especially in the biomedical field.</span></div>
</div>

<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7bb700 lite-page-hidden">1. The densities of dog bone specimens both when hydrated and dry have been reported. Although a trend toward correlation of these two characteristics appears in the material used, such correlation is not to be expected in all bone specimens.
2. The water content of the bone has been correlated with the density of the hydrated specimen.
3. The dry-substance content of the bone has been correlated with the density of the dry specimen. The mass of the dry Specimen largely represents calcified osteoid. Variations in dry density represent in large part more or less complete calcification of the osteoid.
4. In specimens from normal puppies, those with a very low density when hydrated have a slightly lower density when dry and a slightly smaller ratio of ash + carbon dioxide space to organic component.
5. Variations in these relationships probably exist in bones from animals of different species and in disease states affecting bones of animals of any one species.</span></div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Robert-L-Trelstad-49251560" type="button" target="_blank"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname">Robert L. </ul></div>
<div class="nova-legacy-v-publication-item__stack-item"><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-m nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-none nova-legacy-e-text--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-text--clamp-3 nova-legacy-v-publication-item__description"><span class="js-target-abstract-65a1cdb7bbfea lite-page-hidden">Matrix assembly, disassembly, and reassembly of collagenous matrices are dynamic processes which occur when an organism undergoes morphogenesis, growth, repair, or regeneration. They are complex events which ascend the biological hierarchy from molecular interactions among adjacent molecules to macroscopic interactions among adjacent tissues. The multiple levels of organization involved in matrix assembly from molecules to final structure, while not understood, can be appreciated by consideration of your hand: over 90% of the organic matter in the skin, tendons, ligaments, and bones is type I collagen. The genetic and chemical details of type I collagen are relatively well understood and discussed in detail in other chapters; however, the assembly algorithms which partition and position these molecules in three-dimensional space into a functional grasping and holding device are not. In vitro studies of isolated type I collagen and procollagen have indicated that much of the assembly process of a collagen fibril can be explained by physicochemical forces, often described as “self-assembly.” Light microscopic studies of type I collagen-rich tissues reveal a variety of architectures ranging from near-complete molecular alignment in tendons and ligaments; a tight, orthogonal network in bone; and a loose network arrangement in skin (Fig. 7-1). Ultrastructural studies of cells producing type I collagen indicate that fibrils form in association with the cell’s external surface in a complex topographic relationship and that the initial elements formed by the cells are relatively short, discontinuous fibril segments. The relationships of the cell-defined extra-cellular domains with matrix assembly permit cellular regulation of the self-assembly process by the manipulation of the microenvironment and temporal and spatial regulation by determination of the time and place of matrix deposition.</span></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="lite-person-inline-item__image"><picture class="lite-page-avatar lite-page-avatar--size-xs lite-page-avatar--radius-full"> <img src="data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVR42mN89OjNfwAJDwOxHEacwgAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==" data-src="https://i1.rgstatic.net/ii/profile.image/279847952764935-1443732359749_Q64/Sebastian-Bohm-2.jpg" class="lite-image" alt="Sebastian Bohm"></picture></span><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Sebastian-Bohm-2" type="button" target="_blank">Sebastian Bohm</a></span></span></li>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Martin-Tettke-77229394" type="button" target="_blank">Martin Tettke</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">High strain magnitude and low strain frequency are important stimuli for tendon adaptation. Increasing the rate and duration of the applied strain may enhance the adaptive responses. Therefore, our purpose was to investigate the effect of strain rate and duration on Achilles tendon adaptation. The study included two experimental groups (n=14 and n=12) and a control group (n=13). The participants <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdb7bc805","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdb7bc805"> of the experimental groups exercised (14 weeks, 4x/week) according to a reference protocol, featuring a high strain magnitude (~6.5%) and a low strain frequency (0.17 Hz, 3 s loading/3 s relaxation) on one leg and with either a higher strain rate (one-legged jumps) or a longer strain duration (12 s loading) on the other leg. The strain magnitude and loading volume were similar in all protocols. Before and after the interventions the tendon stiffness, Young's modulus and cross-sectional area were examined using magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound and dynamometry. The reference and long strain duration protocols induced significantly increased (p<0.05) tendon stiffness (57% vs. 25%), cross-sectional area (4.2% vs. 5.3%) and Young's modulus (51% vs. 17%). The increases in tendon stiffness and Young's modulus were higher in the reference protocol. Although region-specific tendon hypertrophy was also detected after the high strain rate training, there was only a tendency of increased stiffness (p=0.08) and Young's modulus (p=0.09). The control group did not show any changes (p>0.05). The results provide evidence that a high strain magnitude, an appropriate strain duration and repetitive loading are essential components for an efficient adaptive stimulus for tendons.</span></div>

</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">Introduction: 
The goals of our study were to evaluate the biomechanical differences between five tendons and the changes in biomechanical properties caused by irradiation.

Methods: 
Achilles, quadriceps, semitendinosus + gracilis (STG), tibialis anterior (TA) and the peroneus longus (PL) were harvested from 30 donors. Group A contained 50 tendons without gamma irradiation. The groups were <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdb7bce06","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdb7bce06"> irradiated with a dose of 21 kGy (group B 50 tendons) and with a dose of 42 kGy (group C 50 tendons). The grafts were soaked in a radio-protectant solution and frozen at -80 °C. Cyclic loading tests were performed followed by load to failure tests. Young modulus of elasticity, maximum force, strain at tensile strength and strain at rupture were calculated.

Results: 
The Achilles tendons had significantly lower Young modulus than the TA (p = 0.0036) in group A. The Achilles showed significantly lower than PL (p = 0.000042) and TA (p = 0.00142) in group B and C. The quadriceps and the ST (p = 0.0037) provided poorer values than the TA (p = 0.0432) in group C. We found no difference in maximum loads among the tendons in group A. The maximum load of the Achilles and quadriceps showed better results than the PL (p = 0.0016), (p = 0.0018) and the STG (p = 0.0066), (p = 0.0019) in group C. The TA had similar results like the Achilles and quadriceps.

Discussion and conclusions: 
The vulnerability of gamma irradiation of TA was less than Achilles and quadriceps tendons.</span></div>

<div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-xs nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500"><span>October 1996</span> · <span>Journal of Biomechanics</span></div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Shingo-Odajima-2033944291" type="button" target="_blank">Shingo Odajima</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">Tension-induced structural changes in bovine Achilles tendon collagen at each level of the hierarchy structure were investigated by means of the X-ray diffraction method. In order to estimate the straining mechanism in a collagen fibril, three elementary models for molecular elongation and rearrangement of collagen fibril were proposed on the basis of the Hodge-Petruska model: [1] molecular <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdb7bd2fc","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdb7bd2fc"> elongation, [2] increase in gap region and [3] relative slippage of laterally adjoining molecules. The characteristic 67 nm D-period of a collagen fibril increases with applied force. A Hookean-type force-strain curve was obtained for the D-period while the force-strain relation for the tendon was non-Hookean. The relative intensity of third-order reflection of the D-period to that of the second-order one, I3/I2, decreased with the applied force. This decrease in I3/I2 indicates a decrease in the ratio of the overlap region of collagen fibril to the D-period, O/D, which was analyzed on the basis of the Hodge-Petruska model. Decomposition of the observed strain in the D-period, epsilon(D), into these three deforming modes revealed that the major contribution to epsilon(D) originated from mode [1], molecular elongation. It was deduced that a fibril is mechanically composed of molecules connected serially to each other.</span></div>

<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Andreas-Peper-37743476" type="button" target="_blank">Andreas Peper</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Stefanie-Bierbaum-37742647" type="button" target="_blank">Stefanie Bierbaum</a></span></span></li>
<li class="nova-legacy-e-list__item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item"><span class="nova-legacy-v-person-inline-item__fullname"><a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-inherit nova-legacy-e-link--theme-bare" href="https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/Kirsten-Albracht-39232782" type="button" target="_blank">Kirsten Albracht</a></span></span></li>
</ul><div class="nova-legacy-e-text nova-legacy-e-text--size-s nova-legacy-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-legacy-e-text--spacing-s nova-legacy-e-text--color-grey-500 publication-recommendation-item__abstract">The purpose of the current study in combination with our previous published data (Arampatzis et al., 2007) was to examine the effects of a controlled modulation of strain magnitude and strain frequency applied to the Achilles tendon on the plasticity of tendon mechanical and morphological properties. Eleven male adults (23.9 ± 2.2 yr) participated in the study. The participants exercised one leg <a class="nova-legacy-e-link nova-legacy-e-link--color-blue nova-legacy-e-link--theme-silent js-lite-click" data-lite='{"click":[{"t":".js-target-65a1cdb7bd61e","a":"tc(lite-page-hidden)"},{"t":"self","a":"ac(lite-page-hidden)"}]}'>... [Show full abstract]</a><span class="lite-page-hidden js-target-65a1cdb7bd61e"> at low magnitude tendon strain (2.97 ± 0.47%), and the other leg at high tendon strain magnitude (4.72 ± 1.08%) of similar frequency (0.5 Hz, 1s loading, 1s relaxation) and exercise volume (integral of the plantar flexion moment over time) for 14 weeks, 4 days per week, 5 sets per session. The exercise volume was similar to the intervention of our earlier study (0.17 Hz frequency; 3s loading, 3s relaxation) allowing a direct comparison of the results. Before and after the intervention ankle joint moment has been measured by a dynamometer, tendon-aponeurosis elongation by ultrasound and cross-sectional area of the Achilles tendon by magnet resonance images (MRI). We found a decrease in strain at a given tendon force, an increase in tendon-aponeurosis stiffness and tendon elastic modulus of the Achilles tendon only in the leg exercised at high strain magnitude. The cross-sectional area (CSA) of the Achilles tendon did not show any statistically significant (P > 0.05) differences to the pre-exercise values in both legs. The results indicate a superior improvement in tendon properties (stiffness, elastic modulus and CSA) at the low frequency (0.17 Hz) compared to the high strain frequency (0.5 Hz) protocol. These findings provide evidence that the strain magnitude applied to the Achilles tendon should exceed the value, which occurs during habitual activities to trigger adaptational effects and that higher tendon strain duration per contraction leads to superior tendon adaptational responses.</span></div>
